questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman who has Ca Breast underwent a mastectomy. The ability to extend, adduct, and internally rotate the arm is impaired after mastectomy.
Which muscle's nerve supply has suffered damage?
questions.solution:
• Thoracodorsal Nerve- supplies Latissimus dorsi- Extension, Adduction, Internal rotation of arm
  • Long thoracic Nerve- supplies Serratus Anterior- Overhead(>90) abduction of arm
  • Intercostobrachial Nerve- Sensory supply to skin of upper half of arm.
Above nerves are prone to damage during mastectomy, and therefore patient will not be able to perform these movements. 
Remember- The most common nerve injured during modified radical mastectomy is intercostobrachial nerve ( T2)



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 832

questions.text: Complete transection of the cranial portion of the accessory nerve spares which muscle:
questions.solution:
The Stylopharyngeus muscle is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), so it will remain intact if the cranial section of the Accessory nerve has been completely severed. damage to 11th nerve inturn damages the SLN and RLN damaging muscles of pharynx and palate (except stylopharyngeus and tensor palati) and muscle of larynx (except cricothyroid)

questions.text: The presence of what allows the cervical vertebra to be distinguished from the thoracic vertebra:
questions.solution:
The cervical vertebrae can be distinguished from the thoracic vertebrae by the presence of foramina transversaria. This foramen allows nerves and vessels to pass through.

A typical cervical vertebra possesses a small, wide body; a large, triangular vertebral canal; superior articular facets facing backwards and upwards; inferior articular facets facing downwards and forwards; and the presence of a foramen transversarium.

The second part of the vertebral artery usually passes through the transverse processes of the vertebrae from C1 to C6, with C7 being the exception.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 418,828

questions.text: Find the incorrect statement about the total unilateral Hypoglossal nerve injury:
questions.solution:
Hypoglossal nerve is a pure motor nerve and innervates all the muscles of the tongue except palatoglossus. Therefore, its transection will not result in loss of tactile sensation of the tongue. 

General sensations from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by lingual nerve which is a branch of mandibular division of trigeminal nerve. Injury to lingual nerve will result in loss of general sensations such as touch, temperature, pressure and pain from anterior 2/3rds of the tongue. 

Note- 

1. Taste sensations from anterior 2/3rds of tongue is carried by chorda tympani nerve, a branch of facial nerve. 

2. Taste as well as general sensations from posterior 1/3rd of tongue is carried by glossopharyngeal nerve. 


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 600

questions.text: What mainly regulates CSF pressure?
questions.solution:
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure is regulated by the balance between production and absorption of CSF.

The rate of CSF absorption is predominantly determined by the movement of CSF across the arachnoid granulations (AGs) into the dural venous sinuses.

The absorption of CSF into the venous sinuses is driven by higher pressure in the CSF space as compared to that in the capillaries of the venous sinuses.

The rate of CSF then determines the hydrostatic pressure of CSF in the cranial vault, thereby regulating the intracranial pressure.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 591

questions.text: A newborn displays all of the following responses to cold, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Neonates lack the shivering mechanism because they do not have enough body fat or muscle mass to generate the heat needed to maintain body temperature. Shivering is an involuntary response triggered by cold temperatures, which causes the body to vibrate and produce heat. Neonates' lack of body fat and muscle mass make it difficult for them to generate enough body heat to maintain their body temperatures in cold environments.

questions.text: What is the Critical Closing volume?
questions.solution:
The closing capacity (CC) is the volume in the lungs at which its smallest airways, the respiratory bronchioles, collapse. It is defined mathematically as the sum of the closing volume and the residual volume. Option A- Volume at the end of forceful expiration is residual volume. Option B- Volume at the end of forceful inspiration is total lung capacity. Adult critical closing volume is close to residual volume. "Critical closing volume is the minimum volume and pressure of gas necessary to prevent small airway collapse. It is somewhat near to residual volume. Under pathological conditions when critical closing volume exceeds functional residual capacity, alveolar collapse occurs."

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 564

questions.text: What happens to the blood flow to the brain during light exercise?
questions.solution:
When engaging in physical activity, the body shifts how much blood is routed to various parts. The amount of blood sent to the heart and muscles after moderate to heavy workout increases, whereas the quantity flowing to the liver, kidneys, and internal organs is decreased. However, during light exercise, there is no significant change in blood flow to the brain due to autoregulation. 

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 539

questions.text: Corticospinal damage is linked to all except:
questions.solution:
Superficial reflexes disappear in both upper and lower motor neuron damage.
Clasp-Knife Effect: When the muscles are hypertonic, as in a UMN lesion, the sequence of moderate stretch- strong stretch muscle relaxation is seen. muscle contraction, Passive flexion of the elbow meets immediate resistance as a result of the stretch reflex in the triceps muscle. Further stretch activates the inverse stretch reflex. The resistance to flexion suddenly collapses, and the arm flexes. Continued passive flexion stretches the muscle again, and the sequence is repeated. This sequence of resistance followed by a 'give' when a limb is moved passively is known as the clasp-knife effect because of its resemblance to the closing of a pocket knife. It is also known as lengthening reaction because it is the response of a spastic muscle to lengthening. Clasp knife rigidity occurs due to involvement of Extrapyramidal tracts.
Rest all the 3 are associated with corticospinal tract.

questions.text: Where does ventricular depolarization start?
questions.solution:
Ventricular depolarization starts from the left part of the interventricular septum due to the presence of the specialized conduction system in the heart. This specialized conduction system includes the sinoatrial (SA) node, atrioventricular (AV) node, bundle of His, and Purkinje fibers.

The electrical impulse starts with the SA node and travels through the atria causing them to contract. The electrical impulse then reaches the AV node and spreads to the bundle of His and into the right and left bundle branches.

The electrical impulse then divides and travels down the Purkinje fibers, which are located on the interior wall of the ventricles, causing them to depolarize and contract.

These fibers on the left side of the interventricular septum have a slightly faster conduction velocity and therefore start the ventricular depolarization from the left part of the interventricular septum.

Remember- The sequence of depolarization of heart is endocardium-myocardium-epicardium.

The sequence of repolarization of heart is epicardium-myocardium-endocardium whereas the sequence in an isolated cardiac myocyte is endocardium-myocardium-epicardium.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 529

questions.text: What does fluorescence mean?
questions.solution:
In fluorescence, a photon of high energy (shorter wavelength) light is absorbed by an atom or molecule, causing the elevation of an electron to a higher energy state. As the electron relaxes back to its original energy state, it emits a photon of lower energy (longer wavelength) light. This process of absorption and subsequent re-emission of a longer wavelength of light is known as fluorescence.


Reference: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/fluorescence

questions.text: DNA estimation is possible using:
questions.solution:
DNA estimation by spectrophotometer is a laboratory technique used to determine the concentration and purity of a DNA sample.

It involves measuring the absorbance of the sample at different wavelengths and then calculating an approximate concentration.

This technique can also be used to assess the amount of contamination in a DNA sample and determine if it is suitable for further analysis.

Other options: -
  • Spirometer- measures lung volumes
  • pH meter- measures pH
  • Sphygmometer- measures BP 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 14.

questions.text: Maximum cholesterol-containing food among the following is:
questions.solution:
Eggs contain the most cholesterol out of any food with 1234 mg per 100 gram serving, which is approximately 411% of the Daily Value (DV). If only the yolk is consumed, 210mg of cholesterol is consumed, which roughly makes up 70% of the DV. When the whole egg is consumed, the DV slightly increases to 212mg (around 71%).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 259.

questions.text: When many codons correspond to the same amino acid, this occurrence is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Degeneracy is a feature of the genetic code where more than one 3-nucleotide sequence (called a codon) can code for the same amino acid in a protein. This is also referred to as synonymous codon usage.

The genetic code contains an inherent redundancy, meaning that multiple codons can be used to represent a single amino acid. This means that even if one codon is mutated, a different codon that codes for the same amino acid can be used instead.

This allows some degree of protection against the deleterious effects of certain single-codon mutations, improving the accuracy and reliability of the translated protein.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 433.

questions.text: The final organ to be removed during an autopsy for asphyxia:
questions.solution:
The neck is the last organ to be dissected during an autopsy in death caused by asphyxia because its tissues are most likely to reveal the cause of death.

Asphyxia occurs when the nose, mouth, or throat are blocked or constricted, and when a person expires due to asphyxia, tissue in the neck area may be congested due to the lack of oxygen. Examining these tissues can help determine the exact cause of death by identifying the exact location and type of blockage that led to the asphyxiation.

Furthermore, examining the neck can reveal any signs of trauma that may have contributed to the asphyxia. By examining the neck last, any potential evidence of the cause of death will remain intact and the field would be blood less removing any possibility of artefacts won’t be compromised.

questions.text: A patient committed suicide by shooting a bullet into his right temple. On post-mortem examination, the skull was burst open. There was charring and cherry red discoloration along the track of bullet and the weapon was firmly clasped in the right hand of deceased. The bullet was fired from what distance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1. Contact Shot
 
  • A contact shot is characterized  by charring and cherry red coloration of the track of the bullet as the discharge of the muzzle, comprising flame, powder grains, metallic particles, and hot gases, is blasted into the track.
  • This causes carboxyhemoglobin formation that results in pink coloration of the track. As well, the high pressure of the gases injected into the track from the contact shot can result in bursting of the skull.
Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 221.

questions.text: In estrogen receptor positive breast cancer, the correct anti-estrogen drug to be used is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Tamoxifen
 
  • The drug of choice for estrogen positive breast carcinoma is tamoxifen which is a selective estrogen receptor modulator. 
  • Side effects- Tamoxifen increases the risk of postmenopausal bleeding, endometrial polyps, hyperplasia, and endometrial cancer. 
  • It is also approved by the FDA for the prevention of breast cancer in women at high risk of developing the disease. It has been further approved for the reduction of contralateral (in the opposite breast) cancer.
  • The use of tamoxifen is recommended for 10 years.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 337.

questions.text: Choking is observed in:
questions.solution:
Choking is a process that uses mechanical constrictions at the end of the barrel of a shotgun to shape the spread of the gun’s shot.

The larger internal diameter of the barrel holds more shot, allowing more pellets to be fired with one pull of the trigger. The choke mechanism at the end of the barrel narrows the spread of the shot. 

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 33rd Edition, Page No 362.

questions.text: The organ tested in Breslau's second life test is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Stomach and Intestine

Breslau’s second life test- Test for viability of fetus.
  • Live born infant swallows air into stomach if respiration have occurred. The stomach and intestine are dissected and double ligature are applied at both ends.
  • They are kept under water and incision is given.
  • Air bubbles come out then test is positive. False positive can occur if decomposition have occurred.

Breslau's second life test detects changes in stomach and intestine.
  • Principle: Breslau's Second Life Test (Stomach Bowel test) It assumes that a live born child would respire and therefore would also swallow some air into the stomach and bowel. Thus detecting the presence of air in stomach and intestine (positive test) proves live birth (even in absence of positive hydrostatic lung test if there had been some obstruction in respiratory passage).
  • However, negative test (absence of air in stomach and bowel) does not always mean still-birth since air does not necessarily enter stomach in adequate amounts during act of breathing. Procedure: The stomach and intestine are removed separately after tying double ligature at each end, place them both in water.
  • They float in water if respiration has taken place, otherwise they will sink. No medicolegal value: Because air may be swallowed by child in attempting to free the air passage of fluid obstruction in case of still-birth. It is useless in putrefaction.

Reference: THE ESSENTIALS OF FORENSIC MEDICINE AND TOXICOLOGY, Dr. K.S. NARAYAN REDDY, 34th Edition, Page No 413.

questions.text: In a situation where a patient comes with a cholinesterase level of 30%, a Pinpoint pupil, salivation, tremors, and red tears, the correct diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Organophosphates binds to the enzyme in the body known as cholinesterase. When the enzyme is inhibited, it cannot  breakdown  acetylcholine neurotransmitter, leading to an increase in acetylcholine levels and increased activity of the parasympathetic nervous system.

Therefore, symptoms associated with organophosphate poisoning include pinpoint pupils, excessive salivation, tremors, and red tear. A patient with 30% cholinesterase activity of normal is typically considered diagnostic of organophosphate poisoning.

questions.text: In a situation of a gunshot where a metal bullet is recovered from the body, the primary and secondary markings on the bullet can be used for:
questions.solution: Primary markings on a bullet refer to the markings that are stamped onto it by the manufacturer. These typically include the caliber, bullet type, manufacturer name or logo, and a serial number to track the bullet back to the manufacturer. Secondary markings are used to mark the bullet after it has been fired. These can include a code identifying the type of firearm the bullet was fired from, the location of the gun, or even a specific user.

questions.text: Nephrotic Syndrome-related edema results from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Protein Loss
 
  • Loss of protein is the main mechanism of edema in nephrotic syndrome. 
  • Protein loss, especially albumin results in decreased oncotic pressure at the level of capillary bed which disturbs Frank-Starling's forces and favors movement of fluid from intra-vascular to extra-vascular compartment resulting in edema. 
* [Extra Edge]: Nephrotic Syndrome
  • Nephrotic syndrome is the clinical manifestation of glomerular diseases associated with heavy (nephrotic range) proteinuria.
  • Nephrotic-range proteinuria is defined as proteinuria > 3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein: creatinine ratio > 2.
  • The triad of clinical findings associated with nephrotic syndrome arising from the large urinary losses of protein are hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol > 200 mg/dL).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 116.

questions.text: Which of the following is most oftently used as a fixative in histopathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Buffered Neutral 10% Formalin
 
  • Formalin, used most often in histopathology, is a 4% aqueous solution which is diluted tenfold to create 10% formalin.
  • To maintain its pH and osmotic pressure close to that of extracellular fluid found in mammals, neutral buffered formalin also includes inorganic salts.
  • This type of fixation is different from coagulation, as it acts by attaching to the side-chains of basic amino acids, especially lysine, and the amide nitrogen atoms found in peptide linkages.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 331.

questions.text: In Barrett’s Esophagus:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Intestinal Metaplasia
 
  • Barrett's esophagus is a condition where the normal tissue in the esophagus is replaced by abnormal tissue that resembles the lining of the small intestine with goblet cells. 
  • Diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus is made by endoscopic guided biopsy.
  • Diagnosis of Barrett esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
  • Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles that stain pale blue and impart the shape of a wine goblet to the remaining cytoplasm.
  • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present, but there is not universal agreement as to whether they are sufficient for the diagnosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 761.

questions.text: The most common GERD mechanism is:
questions.solution: The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is a muscle located at the end of the esophagus, just above the stomach. Its primary role is to prevent reflux, or backflow, of stomach acid and other digestive contents into the esophagus. Transient LES relaxation is the most important pathophysiological cause of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). This occurs when the LES fails to close properly and stomach contents reflux up into the esophagus, causing heartburn and other symptoms of GERD.

questions.text: Of the following, which one suggests irreversible cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Amorphous Density in Mitochondria
 
  • Irreversible injury on electron microscopy involves the dilation of mitochondria, which can be seen as an increase in their size. This increase in size typically leads to the appearance of large, amorphous densities.
  • These densities are caused by an accumulation of material within the mitochondria due to the inability of the organelle to properly process, oxidize, and break down nutrients.
  • In other words, the decreased efficiency of the mitochondria prevents the normal breakdown of nutrients, resulting in a build-up of material within the organelle and the appearance of large amorphous densities.
Option 1, 3 and 4 are significant microscopic findings of Reversible injury.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 39.

questions.text: In Lewis Triple Response, what causes skin to turn red when scratched with a pointed object?
questions.solution:
Histamine realeased from damaged local mast cells causes redness.
Lewis triple response is a three-part response by the body to blunt injury. It includes an immediate vascular response, an inflammatory response, and a repair response.

The immediate vascular response involves constriction of blood vessels to stop any further bleeding, followed by vasodilation to increase the damage area’s circulation.

The inflammatory response involves recruiting macrophages, neutrophils, and other immune cells to the site of injury, along with elevated levels of inflammatory biomarkers such as histamine leading to redness, prostaglandins, and cytokines. This response helps reduce swelling and prevent any further damage.

The repair response occurs after the initial damage has been contained by the above responses, and includes building new tissues, such as collagen, to restore the area back to its normal functioning. This response is dependent on proper nutrition in order to ensure that the area is healing.


Reference- Ganong’s Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 601

questions.text: Which drug causes acquired nasolacrimal duct obstruction?
questions.solution: Acquired nasolacrimal duct obstruction is a condition in which the flow of tears from the eye to the nose is blocked. This can be caused by a variety of conditions, including the chronic use of topical medications containing timolol for glaucoma. This is because timolol can cause inflammation and fibrosis of the tissues in the nasolacrimal duct, leading to obstruction of the tear duct and an inability for the tears to drain. Symptoms may include tearing, mucous discharge, crusting around the eyelid margins, and visible dilation of the lower punctum, or tear duct opening. In severe cases, patients may experience infection and chronic irritation of the eyes. Treatment typically involves flushing and topical steroids, with more invasive treatments such as surgery reserved for more severe cases.

questions.text: Drug induced colitis is most frequently associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Clindamycin
 
  • Drug-induced colitis is an inflammation of the lining of the intestine that is caused by allergens, irritants, toxins, or medications.
  • Clindamycin is one of the medications most commonly associated with this condition.
  • The risk of colitis is increased when higher doses of clindamycin are used over a long period of time. Symptoms of drug-induced colitis include abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, fever, and blood in the stool. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 805.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not prohibited by the International Olympic Committee?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cromoglycate
 
  • As analytical science validated improved techniques to identify these drugs, Olympic athletes, including many medalists were caught and disqualified.
  • When the International Olympic Committee (IOC) prohibited beta blockers (beneficial in shooting), diuretics (assist weight classified athletes) and Glucorticosteroids, some athletes with genuine medical conditions were denied legitimate medical therapy.
  • To overcome this, in 1992 the IOC introduced a system known now as Therapeutic Use Exemption (TUE). This paper discusses Olympic athletes who have been known to dope at past Games and some medical indications and pitfalls in the TUE process.

Online Reference:
Fitch K. Proscribed drugs at the Olympic Games: permitted use and misuse (doping) by athletes. Clin Med (Lond). 2012 Jun;12(3):257-60. doi: 10.7861/clinmedicine.12-3-257. PMID: 22783779; PMCID: PMC4953490.

questions.text: What about First Order Kinetics is true?
questions.solution:
Features of zero order kinetics are as follows-

1. Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time. 

2. Rate of drug elimination is independent of plasma concentration. 

3. Clearance is low at low concentration and high at high plasma concentration. 

4. Half life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

5. Examples- Warfarin, Alcohol, Theophylline and Phenytoin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Causes irreversible inhibition of proton pump. Acid secretion suppressed till new pumps are generated
 
  • Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) are a type of pharmaceutical drug used to reduce the production of stomach acid. Despite their relatively short half-lives of around two hours, they can still cause prolonged suppression of acid secretion for up to 48 hours, due to their effect on the proton pumps which produce the acid.
  • The PPIs bind to and irreversibly inhibit the proton pump molecules, meaning that for acid secretion to occur again, new proton pumps need to be synthesized. Therefore, although the PPIs are short-lived, their effects can be prolonged due to the time taken for new proton pumps to be made.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 700.

questions.text: What is false about antiepileptics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Lamotrigine acts by opening of GABA mediated Cl-channels
 
  • The main mechanism of action of lamotrigine is inactivation of voltage gated sodium channels.
  • It also stabilizes presynaptic neuronal membrane and prevents pre-synaptic release of aspartate and glutamate. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 446.

questions.text: Which of the following is likely in a 5-year-old kid who has a history of pyogenic illnesses caused by bacteria with polysaccharide-rich capsules?
questions.solution:
IgA and IgG are the two most abundant antibodies in the body and are important for providing immunity against microbial infections.

In individuals with selective IgA deficiency, they have reduced levels of IgA and/or decreased levels of certain IgG subclasses. As a result, they are unable to provide the necessary protection against bacterial infections, usually caused by encapsulated organisms.

Therefore, recurrent episodes of pyogenic infections caused by capsulated organisms are most commonly observed in people with selective IgA deficiency and decrease IgA or IgG subclass levels (especially IgG2).

questions.text: Which cannot be used to disinfect sputum?
questions.solution:
• Sputum can be sterilized by utilizing autoclaving, boiling or cresol. 
  • Chlorhexidine is a very effective antiseptic for skin but it is not applicable for disinfecting sputum.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 46.

questions.text: Which of the following determines whether an immunoglobin will get secreted or remain membrane bound?
questions.solution:
Alternative splicing—can produce a variety of protein products from a single hnRNA (heterogenous nuclear RNA) sequence (eg, transmembrane vs secreted Ig, tropomyosin variants in muscle, dopamine receptors in the brain, host defense evasion by tumor cells).

 

  • Alternate splicing of the immunoglobulin (Ig) heavy chain gene determines whether the immunoglobulin will be secreted or remain membrane-bound. During B cell development, the splicing mechanism can generate two different forms of the immunoglobulin: a membrane-bound form that is part of the B cell receptor (BCR) and a secreted form that is released into the bloodstream as an antibody.

    The other options are not directly involved in determining whether the immunoglobulin will be secreted or membrane-bound:

    2. Class switching refers to the change in the constant region of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (e.g., switching from IgM to IgG), not whether it is secreted or membrane-bound.

    • 3. Differential RNA Processing is a broader term that could refer to various modifications in RNA, but in this context, alternate splicing specifically controls the secretion or membrane binding.

    • 4. Allelic Exclusion ensures that each B cell produces antibodies from only one allele of the immunoglobulin gene, but it does not affect the secretion vs. membrane-bound decision.

Reference: Harpers Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd edition, Page no 371.

questions.text:
The patient exhibits pneumonia-related symptoms. On sheep agar, the gram positive cocci bacteria isolated from the sputum displayed alpha hemolysis.
Which of the following examinations will support the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This statement refers to the ability of two types of Gram-positive cocci bacteria to form colonies on sheep agar that give off an alpha hemolysis. The two types of bacteria in this instance are Streptococcus viridians and Streptococcus pneumonia. To distinguish between the two bacteria, a test called optochin sensitivity can be used.

The Streptococcus viridians bacteria are optochin resistant, meaning that they are unaffected by the optochin test, while the Streptococcus pneumonia bacteria will be optochin sensitive, meaning that they react to the optochin test.

By testing the optochin sensitivity of the bacteria, it is possible to differentiate between the two types of Gram-positive alpha hemolytic cocci.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 225.

choices.text: Most common mechanism is production of neutralizing substances
Plasmid mediated antibiotic resistance is always transmitted vertically

questions.text: With reference to antibiotic resistance, which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Plasmid mediated resistance is exclusively transmitted horizontally because the plasmid is not incorporated into the chromosome. This means that the plasmid must be shared between individuals through methods such as conjugation, transformation, or transduction in order to be transmitted from one individual to another.

Since all these are horizontal transmission mechanisms, it is implied that plasmid mediated resistance is transmitted exclusively by horizontal transfer. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 18.

choices.text: Chronic Hepatitis B infection with Hepatitis E super infection
Co- infection with Hepatitis B & Hepatitis E

questions.text: The patient has increased SGPT and SGOT, positive HBsAg, negative Anti-HBc IgM, and positive Anti-Hepatitis E IgM. Their Bilirubin level is 0.9 mg/dl. The patient suffers from:
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient was already infected with hepatitis B and after that gets  infected with an acute strain of hepatitis E virus as the patient 's lab reports show 
  • positive HBsAg, negative Anti-HBc IgM- suggestive of chronic infection  of hepatitis B
  •  positive Anti-Hepatitis E IgM- suggestive of acute hepatitis E infection
This is known as  superinfection of hepatitis E on hepatitis B and can cause a more severe form of illness than if the patient had only been infected with either virus alone.

Superinfection occurs when a person is already infected with a particular virus and is then infected with a different strain of the same virus.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 553.

questions.text: A young male patient with urethral discharge showed up. Pus cells were discovered after a urine analysis, but no organisms. Which approach is ideal for  cultures?
questions.solution:
In this case, if the urine examination of a patient with urethral discharge only shows pus cells but no gram-negative diplococci, then it suggests that the patient may have non-gonococcal urethritis. Non-gonococcal urethritis is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, which is a bacterium that needs to be cultured on McCoy cells, HeLa cells, or Hep-2 cells. Therefore, this lab test can help confirm if a patient has non-gonoccocal urethritis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 683.

questions.text: A person working in a butcher shop had hand pustules that developed into ulcers. Which one of the following would aid in diagnosis the most?
questions.solution:
A visible pustule on the hand of an abattoir worker that has progressed to form an ulcer is a presumptive indication of cutaneous anthrax.

Mac-Fadyean's reaction, a test done by staining the lesion with polychrome methylene blue stain, can confirm the diagnosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 251.

questions.text: In the past year, there were 4050 births in a certain demographic. 50 babies were born still. 50 babies passed away within the first week, compared to 150 in the remaining 28 days of the neonatal period. What is the rate of neonatal mortality?
questions.solution:
Total number of births in one year = 4050
Number of stillbirths in that year = 50
Hence, total number of live births in that year = 4000
Total number of infants dying in the first 7 days = 50
Total number of infants dying in the next 28 days = 150
 Hence, total number of infants dying in the first 28 days of birth = 200

NMR = under 28 day deaths/total number of live births in that year = 200*1000/4000
NMR = 50

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 644.

questions.text: Why hasn't leprosy been completely eradicated yet?
questions.solution:
• Leprosy, or Hansen's disease, has not been completely eradicated due to several factors, including:

  • No effective vaccine: While there are some vaccines that may provide partial protection, there is no universally effective vaccine for leprosy.
  • Highly Infectious but low pathogenicity: Leprosy is not highly infectious in the way some diseases are; it requires prolonged close contact for transmission.
  • Only humans are reservoir: This limits the options for controlling the disease, as humans are the sole host.
  • Long incubation period: The long incubation period (often several years) makes it difficult to identify and treat cases promptly, allowing transmission to continue.

  • The most significant reason contributing to the persistence of leprosy is likely the long incubation period, as it complicates control efforts and makes early detection challenging.

    So, the best answer would be 4. Long incubation period.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 362-378.

questions.text: Someone discovered a link between eating fatty foods and ailments brought on by obesity. He accomplished this by gathering information from hospitals and food producers, respectively. What is such a study called?
questions.solution:
An ecological study is an epidemiological study in which data is collected from individuals in certain populations, such as a country.

In this case, the investigator obtained an increased incidence of obesity related ailments  due to a diet high in fatty foods from the health authorities and food industry of the country.

This type of study is useful for determining associations between environmental factors like diet and disease and can help identify potential risk factors for a given condition.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 70.

questions.text: Which of the following can't be used to eliminate bias?
questions.solution:
Multivariate analysis is the study of two or more variables simultaneously in order to make conclusions about the relationships between them. It is performed after the study has been completed, with the goal of examining the collected data.

By contrast, activities such as matching, blinding, and randomization are typically done during the experimental process itself.

Many varieties of bias may arise in epidemiological studies.
Some of these are :
(a) Bias due to confounding : Mention has already been made about confounding as an important source of bias. This bias can be removed by matching in case control studies.
(b) Memory or recall bias : When cases and controls are asked questions about their past history, it may be more likely for the cases to recall the existence of certain events or factors, than the controls who are healthy persons. For example, those who have had a myocardial infarction might be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events than those who have not. Thus cases may have a different recall of past events than controls.
(c) Selection bias : The cases and controls may not be representative of cases and controls in the general population. There may be systematic differences in characteristics between cases and controls. The selection bias can be best controlled by its prevention
(d) Berkesonian bias : A special example of bias is Berkesonian bias, termed after Dr. Joseph Berkeson who recognized this problem. The bias arises because of the different rates of admission to hospitals for people with different diseases (i.e., hospital cases and controls).
(e) Interviewer’s bias : Bias may also occur when the interviewer knows the hypothesis and also knows who the cases are. This prior information may lead him to question the cases more thoroughly than controls regarding a positive history of the suspected causal factor. A useful check on this kind of bias can be made by noting the length of time taken to interview the average case and the average control. This type of bias can be eliminated by double-blinding .

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 80, 81.

questions.text: According to a study, pure vegetarians had a lower incidence of colon cancer than non-vegetarians, and this led researchers to the conclusion that beta-carotene is protective against cancer. This may not be the case since vegetarian subjects may be eating a high-fiber diet that lowers their risk of developing cancer. This is an illustration of:
questions.solution:
A confounding factor is at play in the given study as the presence of high fiber content in vegetarian food is protective against carcinoma colon, which could interfere with the observed protective effect of beta-carotene present in vegetarian food. Therefore, this serves as an example of confounding factor.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 79.

questions.text: Which of the following qualifies as an occupational sickness according to The Workmen's Compensation Act, 1923?
questions.solution:
According to The Workmen's Compensation Act. 1923, anthrax is considered an occupational disease.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 943.

choices.text: To differentiate co-primary cases from secondary cases
To prevent infection to the contacts of the infected person

questions.text: Application of Incubation period is all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
The duration of isolation is determined by the length of time that a person is able to transmit the disease to another person. This is known as the communicability of the disease. Additionally, the effectiveness of the chemotherapy prescribed to treat the disease can have an impact on the transmission of the infection. Thus, the duration of isolation will depend on both the duration of communicability of the disease and the effect that the chemotherapy has on its infectivity.

Incubation period is of fundamental importance in epidemiological studies :

(a) Tracing the source of infection and contacts : In the case of a disease with a short incubation period ranging from a few hours to a few days, it is relatively simple to trace the source of infection-and “follow the trail” of the spread of infection as in the case of food poisoning, bacillary dysentery or typhoid fever. The position is quite different with diseases whose incubation period is of medium length (10 days to 3 weeks) or longer. So many things will have happened and such varied contacts taken place that the cause-effect relationship becomes “diluted”. We will have a whole gamut of possible causes from among which we have to single out the main cause. Once the source of infection is traced, then only it will be possible to institute appropriate control measures.

(b) Period of surveillance : Incubation period is useful in determining the period of surveillance (or quarantine) which may be advised . This period is usually equal to the maximum incubation period of the disease.

(c) Immunization : Prophylactically, a knowledge of incubation period helps us to prevent clinical illness by administering human immunoglobulins and antisera during the incubation period of the disease.

(d) Identification of point source or propagated epidemics : In a point source epidemic, all the cases occur within one incubation period of the disease; in a propagated epidemic, cases occur later than the known length of the incubation period.

(e) Prognosis : Incubation period can also be used in estimating the prognosis of a disease. In some diseases (e.g., tetanus, rabies), the shorter the incubation period, the worse the prognosis of the disease. Thus prognosis is related to the incubation period of the disease .

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 25th edition, Page no 107, 108.

questions.text: What is a reliable indicator for both acute and chronic malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Weight for age (option 1) is a reliable indicator for both acute and chronic malnutrition. It is low in both. If W/A is less than -2SD - child is said to be underweight.  

For Acute malnutrition: Weight for height is more reliable. Weight for height is low only in acute malnutrition, not in chronic. 

For Chronic malnutrition: Height for age is more reliable. Height for age is low only in chronic malnutrition, not in acute malnutrition





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 333,334

questions.text: Which features are true about the Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojna?
questions.solution:
Rashtriya Swasthya Bima Yojana (RSBY) is a Government of India health insurance scheme for the Indian poor which was launched in 2008. It is a health insurance program for Indian citizens living below the poverty line who cannot afford to pay for health care services.

Under the RSBY scheme, the Government provides health insurance cover to households in the Below Poverty Line (BPL) category and to members of the identified occupational groups. The beneficiaries can avail of in-patient and pre-hospitalization medical facilities up to an annual cover of Rs 30,000/- per family per year, with pre-set co-payment that is shared between the beneficiary and Government.

The scheme also provides for cashless treatment for the beneficiary in any of the empanelled hospitals. The benefits of the scheme include access to secondary and tertiary level healthcare facilities and a reduced financial burden arising from sudden hospitalization.

questions.text: Which natural disaster is responsible for the most fatalities?
questions.solution:
• Hydrological disasters, such as floods, storm surges, and mudslides, are among the most destructive and far-reaching natural disasters due to their widespread impact. Unlike earthquakes or volcanic eruptions, which can be very localized, hydrological disasters affect a large area and can cause significant long-term damage.
  • In addition to the physical damage they can cause to infrastructure, hydrological disasters can destroy crops, destroy homes and businesses, and create dangerous conditions such as contaminated drinking water and the spread of waterborne diseases.
  • Hydrological disasters can also cause psychological damage, as the disruption to people’s livelihoods can be devastating. Furthermore, their unpredictability and wide-ranging effects often make them difficult to prepare for. This can lead to a wide-spread loss of life and further economic hardship.
  • Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 922.

questions.text: What is the recommended daily protein intake for female children aged 13 to 15?
questions.solution:
The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR)  2020 guidelines state that the amount of protein a girl aged 13-15 years should consume daily is 0.86 grams/kg/day.

Protein is an important nutrient for building and maintaining healthy muscles and bones, and this recommendation ensures that girls in this age group get the right amount of nutrition during this key period of growth and development.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 749.

questions.text: How long does the re-evaluation of post-polio residual paralysis take in acute flaccid paralysis surveillance?
questions.solution:
Acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) is an infectious disease caused by a number of viruses, including poliovirus.
  • Due to the dangerous nature of the virus, AFP surveillance is conducted by health departments all over the world to monitor for and prevent transmission.
 
  • As part of an AFP surveillance program, all cases of AFP are re-evaluated for residual paralysis at 60 days, to determine whether or not the paralysis was caused by poliovirus.
 
  • This helps health departments determine whether or not a given outbreak is ongoing or has ceased.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 242.

choices.text: Health professional involved in coping strategies, interpersonal skills, adjustment with family
A person involved in finding jobs and economic support for disabled

questions.text: Which of the following best fits the description of a social worker?
questions.solution:
The role of a social worker in health care is a multifaceted one.
  • A social worker's primary responsibility is to help patients, their families, and caregivers work through emotional, financial, and social issues that accompany a diagnosis.
  • They also provide information about community resources, coordinate care, and help patients and their families access services.
  • This includes promoting patient and family involvement in health care decisions and supporting their utilization of available health care resources.
  • As part of their role, social workers also assess a patient's personal role performance, interpersonal skills, and family functions.
  • They provide emotional support, psychoeducational interventions, and systemic advocacy in order to improve quality of life and promote better health outcomes.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 808, 809.

questions.text: The wife of a long-distance truck driver engages in sexual activity and has vaginal discharge. Which medication should be administered in the Syndromic Approach?
questions.solution:
• Metronidazole and Fluconazole are commonly used in the syndromal management of vaginal discharge.
  • Metronidazole is a antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections, including those caused by anaerobic bacteria, while Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections, such as yeast infections.
  • Together they can be used to treat the symptoms of a vaginal discharge.
According to syndromic management its secnidazole plus fluconazole but since the question does not have that answer for vaginal discharge, we can use metronidazole instead of secnidazole.

questions.text: Which of the following is not helpful for the elimination of filariasis?
questions.solution: Conditions advantageous for eliminating lymphatic filariasis are that humans are the only host for the disease and the disease is not spread efficiently by its vector, making it possible to stop transmission should the parasite burden in individuals be reduced sufficiently.
