questions.text: The upper and lower limits of the WHO "Road to Health" chart represent:
questions.solution:
The WHO Road to Health chart represents the measurements of height and weight of babies and young children aged 0-60 months.
  • The upper limit is the 50th percentile, which means that out of 100 children, 50 children will have a height/weight measurement less than or equal to that value.
 
  • The lower limit is the 3rd percentile, meaning that out of 100 children, only 3 children will have a height/weight measurement that is less than or equal to that value.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 622, 623.

questions.text: A red dot is observed during a patient's fundoscopic examination. He has previously been struck by a tennis ball. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution: Berlin's edema, or commotio retinae, is an ocular injury caused by a blunt trauma, such as a tennis ball, to the eye. It usually presents with a red spot at the macula, and is diagnosed based on the patient’s history and eye examination. The prognosis of this injury is usually good, although it may lead to a decrease in visual acuity or temporary vision loss. Treatment typically includes topical corticosteroids and analgesics to help with pain relief and reduce inflammation. In more severe cases, surgery may be necessary to repair any damage to the retina.

questions.text: What is the secondary service center's population target according to Vision 2020?
questions.solution: Under Vision 2020, service center should have one ophthalmologist for a population of 500000.

questions.text: Ophthalmologist per population ratio in Vision 2020 is:
questions.solution:
According to Vision 2020, one ophthalmologist is required for a population of 5 lacs at the level of service centers. 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 504.

questions.text: Dendritic cells possess:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Both HLA1 and HLA 2
 
  • Class 1 HLA antigens are found on all nucleated cells of the body and platelets as well as platelets.
  • Class 2 HLA antigens are present on the surface of antigen presenting cells. 
Since, dendritic cell is a nucleated as well as an antigen presenting cell, it will have both the classes of HLA antigen. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 196.

questions.text: Usually, corneal dystrophies are:
questions.solution:
• Corneal dystrophies are noninflammatory, hereditary corneal disorders which are characterized by bilateral, nonvascularized corneal opacities.
  • They mainly affect a particular layer of the cornea.
  • They are predominantly primary corneal disease i.e not associated with any systemic disease. 


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 186.

questions.text: Which one of the following exhibits a weakness in both adduction and abduction?

A patient had a compressible unilateral proptosis that worsened with forward bending. There was a neither thrill nor bruit. An enhanced retroorbital mass is visible on MRI. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, proptosis increases when bending forward, is compressible without thrill or bruit, and is seen on an orbital ultrasound as an echogenic mass. This is highly suggestive of orbital varix, a condition in which the veins in the orbit swell and become larger.
  • Symptoms may include eye bulging, constriction of vision, double vision, pain, and headaches.
  • Symptoms frequently are exacerbated by changes in head position, bending forward, or by Valsalva maneuver.
  • On MRI T1 images the varix produces a low isointense signal that typically shows marked enlargement in size with Valsalva. On T2 images flowing blood produces a dark signal void. With gadolinium, enhancement is marked, except in areas of thrombus formation where there is little or no enhancement.



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1328, 1329.

questions.text: What can induce a reduction in vision in a patient with anterior uveitis due to posterior segment involvement?
questions.solution:
• Anterior uveitis is an inflammation of the uvea, the middle layer of the eye. It is the most common form of intraocular inflammation, and typically causes redness, pain, photophobia and decreased vision.
  • Uveitis may cause visual loss and blindness due to a variety of causes, including secondary complications such as cataract, glaucoma, choroidal neovascularization, cystoid macular edema, optic neuropathy, and others.
  • In many cases, inflammation of the anterior uvea can cause inflammation in the posterior segment of the eye. In this instance, the inflammation can trigger cystoid macular edema, which is a buildup of fluid in the macula of the eye. The macula is the area at the center of the retina, responsible for central vision.
  • When cystoid macular edema occurs, vision can become blurry and distorted. As a result, overall vision can decrease due to posterior segment involvement.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 700.

questions.text: Retinal area seen with a direct ophthalmoscope is:
questions.solution:
The area of the fundus visualized by direct ophthalmoscopy at any given focus is 2 Disc Diopters (DD). This means that the size of the field of view that can be seen through the ophthalmoscope is roughly twice the size of the disc of the eyeball, which is approximately 1 DD. 



Reference: Parsons’ Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 115, 547.

questions.text: Diabetic Retinopathy and vitreous haemorrhage are both present in this 40-year-old male. What's the reason?
questions.solution:
Diabetic retinopathy is a complication of diabetes caused by damage to the blood vessels of the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye (retina). In an affected individual, these blood vessels become weak and easily damaged, which can lead to bleeding and vision loss.
  • Neovascularization is the formation of new blood vessels produced in response to hypoxia, or low oxygen levels, in the retinal tissue.
  • Neovascularization of the disc, or disc neovascularization, is a common finding in diabetic retinopathy and usually appears as a ring of small, dilated blood vessels around the optic disc.
  • The new blood vessels are often fragile and bleed easily, leading to vitreous haemorrhage, a condition in which the vitreous chamber of the eye becomes filled with blood.


Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 545, 546.

questions.text: Which will be advantageous to patients with Gyrate Atrophy and a deficient Ornithine Transcarbamoylase?
questions.solution:
Gyrate atrophy is a retinal degenerative disease that is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme Ornithine Transcarbamoylase (OTC). This enzyme is responsible for converting ornithine, an amino acid, into other metabolic compounds, such as urea and citrulline.

When the enzyme is deficient, ornithine accumulates and leads to a buildup of waste compounds in the retina, causing various retinal degenerative effects.

Patients with Gyrate atrophy are often advised to follow an arginine-free diet, as arginine is a precursor to ornithine. By restricting the amount of arginine in their diet, they reduce the amount of ornithine in the body and thus the buildup of waste products in the retina, thus improving their condition.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 292.

choices.text: Total action potential represent the endocohlear receptor potential to External auditory meatus
Outer hair cells are responsible for cochlear microphonics and summation potential

questions.text: Regarding Electrocochleography, the correct statement is:
questions.solution: Outer hair cells are auditory cells located in the cochlea of the ear. They are mainly responsible for cochlear microphonics and summation potential, which are critical processes for hearing. Cochlear microphonics is the process whereby pressure changes in the inner ear are converted into an electrical signal. Summation potential is the summation of electrical signals from the inner and outer hair cells which help to amplify sound. This amplification is essential for hearing, as it enables the ear to detect even faint sounds.

questions.text: What is detected by vestibular evoked myogenic potential?
questions.solution: Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential (VEMP) is an auditory-evoked potential generated by the muscle contractions created in response to stimulation of the inferior vestibular nerve of the inner ear. VEMP is used to evaluate the integrity of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) pathway, which mediates the connection between head movement and eye movement. VEMP tests help to assess a patient's vestibular system, providing objective data regarding the integrity of the vestibular nerve as well as the structures responsible for the transmission of vestibular signals. Additionally, VEMP can help in identifying and characterizing peripheral vestibular deficits. It is most commonly used to evaluate a patient's balance and dizziness complaints, making it an important tool for diagnosing vestibular disorders.

questions.text: The second primary tumour of the head and neck is the most commonly suspected malignant tumor of:
questions.solution:
Second primary malignancy of head and neck is a term used to describe a cancer that develops after a patient has been treated for a cancerous tumor that originated in the head or neck. This type of cancer is most commonly associated with the oral cavity, which includes the lips, tongue, floor of the mouth, hard and soft palate, cheeks, and gums. This type of cancer is more common in patients who have had prior radiation therapy or chemotherapy for a malignancy in the head and neck area. The risk of second primary malignancy of the head and neck is increased if the patient is a smoker or has frequent sun exposure.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 258

questions.text: Initial screening test for hearing disorder in newborns is
questions.solution:
Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are sound waves that are generated when the outer hair cells within the inner ear are stimulated. OAEs are used for the medical screening of high-risk neonates in the Intensive Care Unit to determine if a hearing impairment is present.
OAEs can be used to detect any degree of hearing loss and are highly sensitive to changes in both inner and outer ear structures. Screening results are collected within a few minutes and can provide critical information that can be used to make timely decisions about auditory intervention programs.

choices.text: Virus can be found in blood 1 month before jaundice

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for Hepatitis B?
questions.solution: Horizontal transmission is one of the main ways that diseases such as hepatitis B can spread from person to person. This means that the virus is spread from one person to another through close contact or via contact with body fluids from an infected individual, such as blood, saliva or semen. This is why it is important to practice good hygiene and take precautions when engaging in activities such as sexual activity where exposure to these fluids may occur. The American Journal of Gastroenterology states that hepatitis B is the most common mode of transmission of the virus in the world, which highlights the need for increased awareness and education about the importance of practicing safe behaviors in order to help reduce the transmission of the virus.

questions.text: The acid base status of a patient reveals a pH=7.45, pO2=105mm and pCO2=30 mmHg, HCO3-: 20. The patient has partially compensated. Identify the disorder?
questions.solution:
Respiratory alkalosis is a condition in which the blood pH increases due to increased elimination of carbon dioxide from the body. It is caused by hyperventilation. When there is an increase in the amount of carbon dioxide eliminated, the pH of the blood will rise to 7.45 (a slight alkaline reading) and the PCO2 level will decrease to 30mmHg. The overall change is slightly alkaline, and the respiratory change is also alkaline. Therefore, the diagnosis is respiratory alkalosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: Which of the following is a treatment option for heart failure in alternative medicine?
questions.solution:
• Terminalia arjuna is comparable to nitroglycerine in that it helps to relax the coronary arteries and thus, increase blood flow and oxygen supply. This, in turn, results in an increase in exercise capacity and relief from angina pains.
     
  • Additionally, Terminalia arjuna has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that help protect the heart from damage. It may also help to regulate cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of atherosclerosis which is another factor contributing to angina and other forms of heart disease.
 
  • Patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy showed significant symptomatic relief in coronary heart failure from NYHA class III to class I.
 
  • Ultimately, the ingestion of Terminalia arjuna may have effects similar to those obtained when using nitroglycerine for the relief of angina and increasing exercise capacity.



Reference: Dwivedi, S, and R Jauhari. “Beneficial effects of Terminalia arjuna in coronary artery disease.” Indian heart journal vol. 49,5 (1997): 507-10. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9505018/

questions.text: Skin biopsy of an SLE patient shows irregular particulate deposition at the Epidermo-dermal junction after using FITC-labeled human IgG antiserum. It shows the presence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• A skin biopsy of a Systemic Lupus Erythematous (SLE) patient using Fluorescein Isothiocyanate (FITC) labeled human Immunoglobulin G (IgG) antiserum is used to show the presence of immune complex deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction.
  • In SLE, the body's immune system produces high levels of autoantibodies, and these autoantibodies form immune complexes due to a defective clearance from the circulation. These deposits can be seen as irregular particles at the dermal-epidermal junction using FITC labeled IgG antibodies.
  • These deposits are thought to contribute to the skin symptoms of SLE by activating local inflammatory processes that cause damage to the skin and other organs.


Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1051.

questions.text: What causes post-transplant lymphoma/lymphoproliferative disease?
questions.solution:
Post Transplant lymphoma is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
This lymphoma occurs when the immune system of the person who has undergone a transplant is compromised, allowing the EBV to multiply and spread throughout the body. The Epstein-Barr virus is the most commonly associated cause of posttransplant lymphoma and is estimated to be responsible for upto 70% of cases.

questions.text: Which sort of spinocerebellar ataxia is most prevalent in India?
questions.solution:
Spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) is a group of inherited neurological disorders that cause problems with coordination and balance. These disorders are caused by changes in certain genes that control the movement of proteins, which are essential for proper functioning of the brain and nerves.
 
  • SCA2 is the most common form of SCA in India, caused by a mutation of a protein called ataxin-2. This protein is responsible for the functioning of nerve cells and for the proper formation of connections between nerve cells in the brain and spine.
 
  • Individuals with SCA2 experience difficulty with balance, coordination of movements, and speech. They may also experience muscle weakness and involuntary twitching of the body.
 
  • Treatment of SCA2 usually involves medications to improve coordination and maintain muscle strength, as well as physical and occupational therapy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3424.

questions.text: Which structure is most likely to be compressed in a posterior intercommunicating artery aneurysm?
questions.solution:
An aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) or Posterior communicating artery is likely to affect the oculomotor nerve due to its close proximity to the artery. The oculomotor nerve is responsible for controlling the medial and lateral movement of the eye, as well as pupil size and shape.

Aneurysms can cause damage to the oculomotor nerve, resulting in ocular motor dysfunction including ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of eye muscles), impaired vision and abnormal pupil responses. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 931, 937.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 229.

questions.text: What happens in a tension pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Pneumothorax is a condition in which air collects in the pleural cavity between visceral and parietal pleura.

When air is present in the pleural cavity, it causes compression of underlying lung parenchyma and expansion of the chest wall.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 373.

questions.text: What is an erythrocyte intracorpuscular defect?
questions.solution:
Hereditary spherocytosis is a genetic disorder that affects the RBC membrane, causing a deficiency in proteins that stabilize the shape of the cells.

Most common protein to undergo mutation is ankyrin. 

As a result, the red blood cells become more spherical in shape, reducing the surface area and thus the ability of the cell to transport oxygen and other materials efficiently.

questions.text: Anemia and jaundice for two years are present in a 23-year-old female patient. She also complains of oral ulcers. Spherocytes are visible on the peripheral smears. Which investigation is should be conducted?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Coomb’s Test
 
  • In a 23-year-old female with pallor/oral ulcers and spherocytes in the peripheral blood, this is a likely a case of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). AIHA occurs when the body's immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys red blood cells, leading to anemia. Jaundice is occurring due to hemolysis leading to increased indirect bilirubin. 
  • The diagnostic test for AIHA is the antiglobulin test (also called the Coombs' test). This test checks for antibody or complement proteins attached to the outside of red blood cells, indicating that the patient's own antibodies have attacked the blood cells.
Remember- The most common cause of visualization of spherocytes on peripheral blood smear is autoimmune hemolytic anemia and not hereditary spherocytosis. 

Hereditary Spherocytosis would have family history( aurosomal dominant nature) and onset from early childhood. (not in the 20's)

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 649.

questions.text: Which is not a side-effect of growth hormone therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hypoglycemia

* [Extra Edge]: GH therapy in pediatrics age group
  • Rarely, patients develop intracranial hypertension with papilledema, visual changes, headache, nausea, or vomiting. Because of this, funduscopic examination is recommended at the initiation of therapy and at periodic intervals thereafter.
  • The consensus is that GH should not be administered in the first year after treatment of pediatric tumors, including leukemia, or during the first 2 years after therapy for medulloblastomas or ependymomas.
  • Because an increased incidence of type 2 diabetes mellitus has been reported, fasting glucose levels should be followed periodically during therapy. Finally, too-rapid growth may be associated with slipped epiphyses or scoliosis.
* [Extra Edge]: GH therapy in adult age group
  • Side effects associated with the initiation of GH therapy in adults (peripheral edema, carpal tunnel syndrome, arthralgias, and myalgias) occur most frequently in older or obese patients and generally respond to a decrease in dose.
  • Estrogens (e.g., birth control medications and estrogen supplements) inhibit GH action so that a larger dose is needed to maintain the same IGF-1 level.
  • GH therapy can increase the metabolic inactivation of cortisol in the liver.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 930.

questions.text: A male has had anaemia, weakness, and constipation for the past two years. He experiences tummy ache. Most likely diagnosis is:
A patient with hypertension presents with a severe headache in one direction and nausea. A lateralized convex lesion is visible on MRI. His neck is tense. What will the diagnosis be?
questions.solution: In a hypertensive male with sudden onset severe headache, vomiting, and marked neck rigidity without focal neurological deficits, the most likely diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage secondary to ruptured Charcot-Bouchard aneurysm.

questions.text: Drug-induced lupus is not observed with:
questions.solution:
Penicillin does not cause drug induced lupus, also known as SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus). 

Drugs causing lupus are associated with Anti-histone antibodies and have equal incidence in males as well as females. 


Drugs causing Drug-induced Lupus are: [Mnemonic- SHIP]
  • Sulphonamides
  • Hydralazine
  • Isoniazid
  • Procainamide etc.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2749.

choices.text: CML only occurs after 50 years of age
CLL can occur before 10 years of age
ALL in before 1 year has a poor prognosis
Hairy Cell Leukemia has rare splenomegaly and has good prognosis in less than 50 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements about leukemia is correct?
questions.solution:
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in patients under one year of age has a poor prognosis because their young age makes it difficult to tolerate the intensive chemotherapy and radiation treatments needed to treat the disease. 

ALL(Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia) prognostic factors



Response to steroids/ Minimal Residual Disease Negativity/Positivity i.e. response to therapy is
considered the most important prognostic factor.

Other options
  • Option 1 is incorrect - CML can occur at any age but commonly occurs >50 years of age
  • Option 2 is incorrect - CLL is a disease of the elderly and only occurs beyond 50 years of age
  • Option 4 is incorrect - Hairy cell leukemia commonly has massive Splenomegaly 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 819, 828-834, 856.

questions.text: Patient is suffering from a pneumococcal brain abscess. For antibiotic sensitivity, a culture is sent. Which antibiotic is administered empirically till the arrival of culture sensitivity result?
questions.solution: Empiric therapy of community-acquired brain abscess in an immunocompetent patient requires two antibiotics to be used in combination. The use of a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin, such as cefotaxime, ceftriaxone or cefepime, is recommended as the first line of treatment. Metronidazole is added as the second antibiotic due to its broad spectrum of activity and its ability to penetrate into cerebrospinal fluid. This combination of antibiotics is empirically used to treat community-acquired brain abscesses in an immunocompetent patient to help reduce the risk of antibiotic resistance and to increase the chances of a successful treatment.

questions.text: Pseudotumor Cerebri is usually seen in:
questions.solution:
• Pseudotumor cerebri, also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, is a neurological disorder characterized by increased pressure in the cranial cavity which can result in severe headaches, blurred or double vision, or even vision loss.
 
  • It is most commonly seen in obese women between the ages of 20 and 45. This is because increased pressure in the brain is more likely to occur in those with a higher amount of intra-abdominal fat, which pushes up on the diaphragm and therefore increases pressure on the cranial cavity.
 
  • Age also plays a role because it is more common in this age range among women.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: Photosensitivity is a symptom of Porphyria. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies do not have photosensitivity?
questions.solution:
In porphyrias, the enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis are defective, leading to the accumulation of toxic intermediates. While many porphyrias manifest with photosensitivity, some do not. The enzymes involved in porphyrias without photosensitivity are: 1. Hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS) - 2. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase (UROS) - 3. Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) - 4. Aminolevulinic acid synthase. These enzymes are involved in the early stages of heme biosynthesis, and their deficiencies lead to the accumulation of toxic intermediates that primarily affect the nervous system, rather than the skin, resulting in neurovisceral symptoms without photosensitivity.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 310.

questions.text: Since two years ago, a 60-year-movements old's have been gradually slowing down. She moves in a rectangular, slow wave jerking fashion and exhibits rigidity. The likelihood of a diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurological disorder that affects movement and causes stiffness, decreased movement, and an inability to control eye movements. The cause of PSP is unknown. It typically affects individuals over the age of 60 and its symptoms are progressive.

Clinical features and progression: 
 
  • Clinically, PSP-RS begins with falls and executive or subtle personality changes (such as mental rigidity, impulsivity, or apathy).
  • Shortly thereafter, a progressive oculomotor syndrome ensues that begins with square wave jerks, followed by slowed saccades (vertical worse than horizontal) before resulting in progressive supranuclear ophthalmoparesis.
  • Dysarthria, dysphagia, and symmetric axial rigidity can be prominent features that emerge at any point in the illness. A stiff, unstable posture with hyperextension of the neck and a slow, jerky, toppling gait are characteristic.
  • Frequent unexplained and sometimes spectacular falls are common secondary to a combination of axial rigidity, inability to look down, and impaired judgment.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3380.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatic fever is allergic to penicillin. Which drug from the list below should be recommended?
questions.solution:
Sulfisoxazole is an alternative antibiotic for patients who are allergic to penicillin. It can be prescribed to patients with a history of repeated episodes of rheumatic fever, who are also allergic to penicillin.

Rheumatic fever is caused by untreated strep throat and can cause serious damage to the heart valves if not treated properly.

Sulfisoxazole can effectively treat strep throat, allowing patients with a history of rheumatic fever to avoid further damage to their heart valves.

questions.text: A newborn has bleeding from the umbilical stump. All the basic coagulation work up (Platelet count, PT/aPTT) was normal. Most probable cause of bleeding is:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option 1 - Factor XIII deficiency.

From an entrance exam point of view, whenever the examiner asks for bleeding from the umbilical stump, one has to think of two conditions- Factor 13 deficiency and Glanzmann Thrombasthenia.  Since, Glanzmann Thrombasthenia is not there in options - the best answer is factor XIII deficiency. 

Factor XIII Deficiency
  • Factor 13 (Fibrin stabilizing factor ) deficiency is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.
  • Factor XIII is responsible for cross-linking fibrin strands to stabilize the clot. In its absence, initial hemostasis and coagulation appear normal -hence, normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT. However, clots formed are unstable and break down, leading to delayed bleeding, especially from the umbilical stump in neonates
  • It is  also characterized by  poor wound healing, and wound dehiscence.
  • Platelet count, PT, aPTT and INR are normal. (as given in the clinical stem)

Other options

Option 2 -  von Willebrand Disease - Causes mucocutaneous bleeding not umblical stump bleeding and has prolonged aPTT ( not normal aPTT)

Option 3 - Haemophilia A- causes deep seated bleeds like bleeding in joints/muscle hematoma and factor VIII deficiency leads to prolonged aPTT

Option 4 - Bernard Soulier Syndrome - deficiency of GpIB on platelet leads to defective platelet adhesion and characterised by low platelet counts and muco-cutaneous bleeds.


Reference:  https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/209179-workup

questions.text: Which scientific principle is the basis for thermodilution method used in measurement of cardiac output by Pulmonary Catheter?
questions.solution:
• The Stewart-Hamilton equation is the foundational element of the thermodilution technique applied to measure cardiac output using a pulmonary catheter.
 
  • The indicator dilution technique has become the de-facto clinical standard for measuring cardiac output due to its simplicity and extensive past usage in multiple contexts.

 
  • This technique requires injecting a known quantity of a substance into a peripheral vein and then monitoring the alteration of its concentration in repeat arterial sampling. 



Reference: Argueta, Erwin E MD*; Paniagua, David MD†. Thermodilution Cardiac Output: A Concept Over 250 Years in the Making. Cardiology in Review 27(3):p 138-144, May/June 2019. | DOI: 10.1097/CRD.0000000000000223. URL: https://journals.lww.com/cardiologyinreview/fulltext/2019/05000/thermodilution_cardiac_output__a_concept_over_250.5.aspx

questions.text: The most common presentation of immunoproliferative small intestinal disease is:
questions.solution:
• IPSID, also known as Mediterranean Lymphoma, is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the small intestine caused by infection with the bacteria Campylobacter jejuni. It is most commonly seen in patients of Middle Eastern, North African and Central Asian origin.
 
  • The most prominent feature of this disorder is malabsorption. This can lead to diarrhea, weight loss, abdominal pain and loss of appetite.
 
  • Other symptoms that may be seen with IPSID include fever, anemia, and an enlarged spleen.
 
  • Patients with this condition will often require lifelong antibiotic treatment to control the infection and may also need nutritional supplementation to ensure proper nutrition.


Reference: Martin, I G, and M I Aldoori. “Immunoproliferative small intestinal disease: Mediterranean lymphoma and alpha heavy chain disease.” The British journal of surgery vol. 81,1 (1994): 20-4. doi:10.1002/bjs.1800810107. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8313111/

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2459.

questions.text: The cause of "Fever Blister" is
questions.solution:
Fever blisters are caused due to reactivation of latent HSV-1 virus
 
  • Oral lesions of the mouth such as fever blisters or cold sores are usually associated with recurring infection rather than with the first infection.
  • These skin lesions caused by Herpes simplex virus Type-1 (HSV-1) usually occur on the face, particularly the cheeks, chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead. On occasion, lesions may also appear on an infant's buttocks, commonly referred to as a 'napkin rash'.
  • Fever blisters or herpes febrilis is the most typical lesion and happens when the viral infection is reactivated due to elevated body temperature.




Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 459, 463.

questions.text: Blood alcohol level of an alcoholic with poor judgment and decreased in skilled movements would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) 80-200 mg/dl
 
  • Alcohol intoxication occurs when an individual has consumed a large enough quantity of alcohol to raise their blood alcohol content level past the legal limit of 0.08%.
  • At blood alcohol levels between 80-200 mg/dl, the individual will exhibit a number of impairments, primarily related to motor coordination and judgment. These impairments may include slurred speech, blurred vision, and unstable balance, poor judgment, and lack of coordination.
  • At higher levels of intoxication > 300 mg/dl, more serious impairments can occur, such as unconsciousness, coma, and even death in extreme cases.
* [Extra Edge]: Serum Ethanol level Vs Symptoms



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 522.

questions.text:
Symptoms of a 56-year-old male include a unilateral headache, diplopia, and fever. He found it challenging to chew. ESR was higher and the brain MRI results were normal.
What is the treatment advisable?
questions.solution:
• This individual is likely to be suffering from temporal (giant cell) arteritis, which is an inflammatory disorder often affecting the large  arteries, usually those found in the head, including those leading to the eyes and the temples.

 
  • In order to confirm the diagnosis, the patient's erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) must be persistently high along with normal results on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. As this condition is highly serious and can cause permanent damage to the arteries, treatment needs to start before confirmation of the diagnosis.

 
  • The initial treatment plan consists of high-dose prednisolone or corticosteroid therapy which helps reduce the inflammation in the arteries. This can help to slow or stop the progression of the condition and possibly reverse any damage caused.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2812.

questions.text: The type of wave in metabolic encephalopathy is:
questions.solution: In metabolic encephalopathy (also known as toxic-metabolic encephalopathy), the electrical activity of the brain as seen on an EEG (electroencephalogram) will most likely show delta activity. Delta activity is characterized by slow, high voltage brain activity that is usually found in a deep sleep state. In metabolic encephalopathy it can indicate a decrease in alertness and poor brain functioning due to a metabolic disturbance.

questions.text: One of the two patients with atherosclerosis has diabetes, whereas the other does not. Diabetic patients are 100 times more likely than non-diabetics to have:
questions.solution:
• The incidence of lower limb ischemia is increased 100 times in patients with diabetes due to the hardened and narrowed arteries caused by high levels of sugar present in the bloodstream.
 
  • The narrowing of the arteries reduces the amount of blood that flows to the lower limbs, thereby increasing the risk of decreased oxygen levels to the limbs and leading to tissue damage.
 
  • The high blood sugar levels also make the blood more viscous, causing it to flow more slowly and resulting in greater chance of a blockage and lower limb ischemia.
  • Other complications are also increased but not 100 times as limb ischemia


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3127.

questions.text: The most vital factor in the "Pneumonia Severity Scale" is:
questions.solution:
• Age is one of the most important factors in assessing the risk of fatality among adults from the Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI). It is well established that the older a patient is, the higher the risk of fatality.
 
  • Other important factors assessed by the PSI include the presence of other medical conditions, laboratory findings, and the patient’s vital signs.
 
  • However, age is the most reliable predictor of the potential severity of a pneumonia case, and is therefore the most important factor when assessing risk.

Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI):




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1012.

questions.text: A little youngster has acute pyelonephritis. What is the most precise urinary finding?
questions.solution:
• WBC casts are specific urinary findings in acute pyelonephritis, a urinary tract infection that can affect the kidneys.
  • This type of cast is a collection of white blood cells (WBCs) that form within the renal tubules of the affected kidney. These casts indicate that the infection is not just affecting the bladder, but has spread to the kidneys and is causing inflammation.
  • They can be seen under a microscope and are often seen in cases of severe infection.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2304.

questions.text: A woman  with meningioma with Perilesional edema was posted for surgery. The error made by a junior resident when writing pre-op notes is:
questions.solution:
• Perilesional edema or vasogenic edema is a type of swelling that can occur in the brain after a cerebral infarct, or stroke or surrounding a tumour. It occurs when the blood-brain barrier (BBB) is damaged and the brain is no longer able to maintain adequate homeostatic control of the interstitial pressure.
  • Steroids are commonly used to reduce the edema, lower the intracranial pressure and improve symptoms. Therefore, it is important to continue taking the steroids and make sure to take the morning dose.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 27th edition, Page no 664, 665.

questions.text: A lady suffered from arthralgia, uveitis, and shortness of breath. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis is a non-caseating granulomatous multisystem disease with a wide range of clinical and radiographic manifestations. 

Clinical presentation is variable and diagnosis is usually made on the combination of clinical and radiological features.

  • half of the patients are asymptomatic
  • the rest develop respiratory (e.g. cough and dyspnea) or skin (e.g. erythema nodosum, lupus pernio, scars, plaques) disease 
  • ocular, lacrimal gland and salivary gland involvement are relatively common
  • approximately 5% of patients develop neurosarcoidosis.

Additionally, patients may have specific syndromic presentations:

  • Löfgren syndrome: an uncommon but specific acute presentation of sarcoidosis with a better prognosis
  • Heerfordt syndrome: an uncommon variant of sarcoidosis comprising of fever, parotid enlargement, facial palsy, and anterior uveitis

questions.text: For the past four years, a 46-year-old man has suffered from constipation, abdominal pain, mucous in his stool, and a sense of incomplete evacuation. On examination, there was left iliac fossa tenderness. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Diverticular disease of the colon is characterized by small outpouchings that project from the colonic wall (diverticula) and then become inflamed and/or infected. (Diverticulitis)
  • Symptoms of diverticulitis can include abdominal pain, mild constipation, a feeling of incomplete evacuation, and mucus in stools.
  • Tenderness in the left iliac fossa is a common symptom of diverticular disease and would be suggestive of the diagnosis in a 40-year-old male patient.

questions.text: Hematopoietic Stem Cells differ from Committed Progenitor Cells in being able to?
questions.solution:
Hematopoietic stem cells are examples of multipotent cells whereby they can form more than one category of cells such as myeloid and lymphoid lineage. Committed progenitor cells, on the other hand,  are examples of oligopotent cells where they can form only one category of cells- example- erythroblast. 

unique properties of HSC -
1. Asymmetric division- self renewal 
2. Not sessile - they can be mobilised to peripheral blood - eg: Sepsis, GM-CSF administration 
3. Transdifferentiation/Developmental plasticity- can be converted to other lineage of cells like neurons, muscles etc

 

Reference-: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease Edition 10 th Page no 544

questions.text: What kind of cells does the researcher find when he injects myeloid stem cells into an ablated animal following the incubation period?
questions.solution: https://www.cell.com/cms/attachment/0436a1d2-a7e1-40d2-85bc-9f5bf7c9ce5d/gr1.jpg

questions.text: Among the following, where can decelerations cause the aorta to rupture?
questions.solution: The most common site for aortic rupture is in the region of ligamentum arteriosum as proximal to this region, the aorta is enclosed in a relatively immobile fibrous pericardium whereas distal to it, it is relatively mobile as it does not have pericardial covering.

questions.text: Cardiomegaly was discovered in a woman who had cold intolerance and hoarseness of voice. What investigation needs to be done to determine the cause?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is of dysphagia lusoria, i.e. hoarsness of voice due to RLN compression by enlarged left ventricle. 
  • Echocardiography is a noninvasive imaging test that uses sound waves to produce images of the heart and its surrounding structures.
  • It is useful in detecting enlargements of the heart, which is an indicator of cardiomegaly. With echocardiography, doctors can evaluate the size and shape of the heart and the thickness of the heart walls.
  • It can detect any obstructions in the blood flow, changes in the heart valves, and other abnormalities.
  • The images can then help in determining the underlying cause of cardiomegaly and in creating an effective treatment plan.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1832, 1833.

questions.text: Midsystolic click is heard in a female. Pathology seen in mitral valve is:
questions.solution:
• It appears that the clinical signs indicated in the question point to Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome (MVP).In the event of an inspection of the cells and tissues, a myxomatous degeneration and the falling back of the mitral valve are likely results to be seen in Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome.
 
  • Mitral valve prolapse syndrome is a condition in which the mitral valve, which separates the upper and lower chambers of the heart, bulges abnormally into the left atrium. It is the most common form of heart valve disorder.

 
  • Symptoms of mitral valve prolapse range from no symptoms to a wide variety of uncomfortable symptoms and can include chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Other common symptoms may include dizziness, fainting, anxiety, dry cough, and significant fatigue.
  • Patients may also suffer from a palpitation when the mitral valve fails to close properly and a murmur may be heard. In some cases, mitral valve prolapse can cause a leak in the valve, leading to even greater issues such as heart arrhythmia and congestive heart failure.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2000.

questions.text: What is the most important risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Hepatitis B

Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a virus that can cause an acute or chronic liver infection.
Chronic HBV infection is a major risk factor for the development of liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 326.

questions.text: Streptokinase and warfarin are given to a patient who has transmural thrombi. After which further testing should thrombolysis be stopped?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Pericardial Effusion
 
  • Fibrinolytics and anticoagulants can be continued in case of pericarditis, however, once significant pericardial effusion develops after MI, fibrinolytics should be discontinued.
  • The risk of post MI pericardial effusion is not increased with the use of fibrinolytic agents, heparin, aspirin and other antiplatelet agents.
  • In contrast, a pericardial effusion occurring in the setting of MI is an indication to discontinue anticoagulation and fibrinolytics.
  • As soon as pericardial effusion is established by echocardiography, emergency percutaneous pericardiocentesis should be performed at 20 +/- 6 h after thrombolytic therapy was started.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2056, 2020.
Renkin J, de Bruyne B, Benit E, Joris JM, Carlier M, Col J. Cardiac tamponade early after thrombolysis for acute myocardial infarction: a rare but not reported hemorrhagic complication. J Am Coll Cardiol. 1991 Jan;17(1):280-5. doi: 10.1016/0735-1097(91)90739-v. PMID: 1898952. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1898952/

questions.text: What is the time period in which a patient with AMI can be given thrombolytic treatment?

questions.text: An elderly hypertensive patient who was taking aspirin, sorbitrate, and atenolol unexpectedly lost his balance in the restroom. Family members noticed black stools. He had tachycardia and hypotension when he entered the ER. What is the current diagnosis?
questions.solution: The most likely diagnosis based on given clinical scenario is perforated peptic ulcer disease with shock.

choices.text: Amyloid Angiopathy is associated with Small Vessel Disease
Alzheimer's Disease is associated with Amyloid Angiopathy
Alzheimer's Disease is related to small vessel Disease
Alzheimer's Disease is not related to small vessel Disease

questions.text: All are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
It has been seen that deposition of amyloid is aggravated in patients with cerebral small-vessel disease, especially in apolipoprotein E4 carriers, providing evidence for pathophysiological synergy between these three biological factors
 
  • The accumulation of Aβ in cerebral arterioles is termed amyloid angiopathy. Thus, amyloid angiopathy is a small vessel disease whi is also seen in patients with Alzheimer's disease.
  • In Alzheimer's disease Microscopically, there are widespread neuritic plaques containing amyloid beta (Aβ), neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) composed of hyperphosphorylated tau filaments, and Aβ accumulation in blood vessel walls in cortex and leptomeninges (amyloid angiopathy).
  • Also, in many patients with AD, amyloid angiopathy can lead to microhemorrhages, large lobar hemorrhages, ischemic infarctions most often in the subcortical white matter, or in rare cases an inflammatory leukoencephalopathy.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3349, 3370-3372.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures should not be followed in the treatment of a patient with atrial fibrillation who has a clot in the left atrium?
questions.solution: Left atrial thrombus is a contraindication for DC cardioversion since the thrombus can get dislodged and throw an embolus anywhere in the body.

questions.text: A 10 year old child develops arrhythmia, metabolic and respiratory acidosis on arterial blood gases and elevation of end tidal CO<sub>2</sub>.  Start of the treatment should be with
questions.solution: Malignant hyperthermia is a rare but potentially deadly reaction to certain anesthetic agents and succinylcholine. It is caused by an inherited genetic defect that affects the body's ability to regulate its temperature in the presence of these agents. During a malignant hyperthermia episode, the body quickly increases its temperature, heart rate and blood acidity, which can lead to muscle spasms, seizures, and shock if untreated. Signs of malignant hyperthermia include sudden development of increased heart rate, arrhythmia, high fever, metabolic and respiratory acidosis on arterial blood gases, and elevation of end tidal CO2. If malignant hyperthermia is suspected, the first agent of choice in the management of the episode is dantrolene, which helps to inhibit muscle contraction and prevent further heat generation, with supportive interventions such as cooling and ventilation to stabilize the affected individual.

questions.text: What is the most reliable test for diagnosing spinal TB?
questions.solution: A CT-guided biopsy is considered the most reliable test for diagnosing spinal tuberculosis because it can accurately detect the presence of bacteria that cause tuberculosis. In addition, it allows doctors to sample tissue and fluid from the infected area, allowing for a more specific diagnosis. By testing the affected tissue more directly, the accuracy of the diagnosis is greatly increased compared to other methods.

questions.text: Among the following what is not seen in massive acute blood loss?
questions.solution:
Decrease in PCV and not increase will be seen in massive acute blood loss.
 

  1. Reticulocyte count: In response to acute blood loss, the body increases red blood cell production, leading to a rise in reticulocytes (immature red blood cells) within a few days.

  2. PCV (Packed Cell Volume): After acute blood loss, the PCV (hematocrit) usually decreases because blood volume is reduced, leading to a lower proportion of red blood cells relative to plasma.

  3. MCV (Mean Corpuscular Volume): The MCV can increase slightly in response to reticulocytosis since reticulocytes are larger than mature red blood cells.

  4. Neutrophils: Neutrophils often increase in acute blood loss due to the body's stress response.

Thus, an increase in PCV is not typical of massive acute blood loss.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 776, 792.

questions.text: Which of the following matches is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Moya Moya disease is a progressive neurological disorder which is characterized by narrowing or blockage of the blood vessels leading to the brain.
  • Moyamoya disease is a poorly understood occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries, especially the distal internal carotid artery and the stem of the MCA and ACA. Vascular inflammation is absent.
  • The lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion, which gives the impression of a “puff of smoke” (moyamoya in Japanese) on conventional x-ray angiography.
  • It is most commonly diagnosed in children and is associated with the narrowing and occlusion of the circle of Willis and arteries that feed it, as well as the presence of abnormal and collateral vessels within the brain.
  • It is not associated with aortic aneurysms, which are conditions where a weakened area in the aorta bulges out, forming a balloon-like structure, and can be life-threatening if the aneurysm ruptures.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3343.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate management for a patient who has tenderness in the left iliac fossa with a 3-cm stone in the renal pelvis and no hydronephrosis?
questions.solution:
Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is an ideal management for a female patient with a 3 cm left renal pelvic stone with no hydroureteronephrosis or distal obstruction, and normal functioning kidneys on both sides.
  • PCNL is minimally invasive, and can successfully treat stones of any size and location.
  • It also reduces the risk of urine leakage and stone fragments, and allows for quick stone clearance and shorter recovery times.
  • The procedure involves a small incision in the back through which a tiny telescope is inserted to view the stone, a laser to break up the stone and enable removal, and nephrostomy tubes to flush out the fragments.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1477.

questions.text:
A patient with hematemesis was examined, and his blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg and his heart rate was 120. There was also splenomegaly.
What is the most probable cause of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Portal hypertension is a condition in which the pressure in the portal vein (the primary vein that carries blood from the intestines, pancreas, spleen, and stomach to the liver) is abnormally high.

Splenomegaly (enlarged spleen) and massive bleeding due to rupture of gastric varices leading to hypotension and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are symptoms often seen in patients with portal hypertension. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2625.

questions.text: Patients who have had their parotid gland removed report sweating on their cheeks when eating. What is fused with the auriculotemporal nerve, which contains parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland?

Perform Laparotomy and check for leakage site and healthy margins
Perform Laparotomy and completely exteriorize the fistula
Perform Laparotomy and place lateral drains and leave

questions.text: A resection anastomosis was performed on a patient with Crohn's disease. The patient exhibits a fistula-related anastomotic site leak on the seventh postoperative day. The total amount of daily leakage is 150–200 ml. The patient is stable and uncomplaining; there is no intra-abdominal collection. What level of management will come after that?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is Do conservative management and leave it for spontaneous resolution.

The likely diagnosis is a very low output enterocutaneous fistula. Daily output less than 500 ml is low output fistula. 
The patient is stable with no collection of fluid in the abdomen, indicating that the fistula is not actively leaking.

The ideal management in this case is conservative management which includes nutritional support, wound care, and regular follow-up. 

* Principles of management of enterocutaneous fistulae (SNAP):

S, elimination of Sepsis and skin protection
N, Nutrition – a period of parenteral nutrition may well be required
A, Anatomical assessment
P, definitive Planned surgery

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1315.

questions.text: What is the treatment for a patient who has dysphagia and sporadic epigastric discomfort during endoscopy whose oesophagus is dilated proximally and narrowed distally?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Heller’s Cardiomyotomy.

Achalasia is a rare and very specific type of esophageal disorder that affects both the muscles and nerves of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES). This leads to difficulty in swallowing, chest pain and sometimes vomiting.

It is usually diagnosed after a physical exam and radiologic imaging studies, such as barium swallow and CT scan which reveal dilation of the esophageal lumen with narrowing of its distal end.

Heller’s cardiomyotomy is the treatment of choice for achalasia cardia, which involves surgically dividing the lower esophageal sphincter muscle and the inner muscle layer of the esophageal wall. This helps with opening up the esophageal lumen, and prevents the episodes of chest pain and dysphagia that are seen in achalasia.


Fig: Completion of the myotomy; the light of the endoscope can be seen shining through the thin mucosa

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1315.

questions.text: Which cyst in the jaw is precancerous?
questions.solution:
Odontogenic Keratocyst (OKC) is a type of cyst that usually develops in the jawbones.
  • It is generally considered a benign lesion, however, some studies indicate that OKC may be a premalignant condition.
  • This means that, while the cysts are not cancerous or malignant, they could potentially progress to become cancerous or malignant in some cases.
  • It is important to receive proper diagnosis and treatment to ensure that these cysts don't become cancerous or spread to other areas in the body.
Reference: SRB's Manual Of Surgery, Sriram Bhat M, 6th Edition, Page No 349.

questions.text: Due to which factor does a person suffer leg weakness following a thoracoabdominal transplant?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the likely cause for lower limb weakness following thoracoabdominal transplant is lumbosacral nerve injury. 

The various causes of lumbosacral plexopathy are as follows- 
  • Trauma - direct injury or traction on the plexus
  • Tumor - direct infiltration by the tumor or metastasis, intra-neural lymphomatosis, the perineural spread of prostate cancer
  • Radiation - This leads to endothelial damage leading to chronic inflammatory cell migration and a state of fibrosis, followed by an irreversible state of microvascular injury and ischemic damage
  • Hematoma - Direct compression
  • Diabetic and non-diabetic LS plexopathies - caused by inflammatory or microvascular changes

choices.text: Located below the umbilicus and always in the midline
Located above the umbilicus and always in the midline
Located above the umbilicus and on either side

questions.text: Which of the following statement is correct about an epigastric hernia?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 2. Located above the umbilicus and always in the midline.

Explanation:

An epigastric hernia is a type of abdominal wall hernia that occurs in the epigastric region, which is the area of the abdomen above the umbilicus and typically between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus. It occurs in the midline of the abdomen, along the linea alba (the fibrous structure that runs vertically in the midline of the abdomen).

Let's review the options:

  1. Located below the umbilicus and always in the midline:
    This is incorrect. An epigastric hernia is located above the umbilicus, not below it. Hernias located below the umbilicus are typically umbilical hernias.

  2. Located above the umbilicus and always in the midline:
    This is correct. Epigastric hernias occur in the epigastric region, which is located above the umbilicus, and they typically occur in the midline of the abdomen along the linea alba.

  3. Located above the umbilicus and on either side:
    This is incorrect. Epigastric hernias occur in the midline, not on either side of the umbilicus. Hernias on either side of the umbilicus are more likely to be inguinal or ventral hernias.

  4. Can be seen anywhere on the abdomen:
    This is incorrect. Epigastric hernias are specifically located above the umbilicus and in the midline. Other types of hernias (e.g., umbilical, inguinal, femoral, incisional) can occur in different locations on the abdomen.

Conclusion:

An epigastric hernia is typically located above the umbilicus and in the midline, making option 2 the correct statement.



Fig: Epigastric hernia

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1074.

questions.text: External hemorrhoids, distal to dentate line
questions.solution: External hemorrhoids distal to the dentate line have somatic innervation from internal pudendal nerve S2S3S4 and are therefore painful.

questions.text: What's the early complication of ileostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Necrosis

Ileostomy is a surgical procedure where a stoma (or hole) is created in the abdominal wall, allowing the small intestine to enter into an artificial external opening.

Among the given options, necrosis is an early complication ( < 30 days ) of ileostomy. Rest of the given options are delayed complications. 

* Stoma complications:

Skin irritation
Prolapse
Retraction
Ischemia
Stenosis
Parastomal hernia
Bleeding
Fistulation


Fig: Spouted ileostomy in the right iliac fossa

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1315.

questions.text: Which of the following does not constitute Ca breast stage T4b ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Nipple Retraction

T4b -- Ulceration and/or ipsilateral macroscopic satellite nodules and/or oedema (including peau d’orange) of the skin that does not meet the criteria for inflammatory carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following has improved in terms of prognosis as a result of advances in cancer treatment?
questions.solution:
Approximately 30% of all pediatric cancers are of the Acute leukemia form.
  • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is encountered five times more often than acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
  • Since the 1980s, there have been considerable developments which have improved the five-year overall survival rate of ALL to over 85%.
  • These advancements have come with the aid of research protocols which offer sequential, standardized treatments for numerous children.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 594-599

questions.text: After a typical vaginal delivery at full term, the woman experiences hypoxemia and then collapses unexpectedly. What causes this?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Amniotic fluid embolism

The sudden unexpected hypoxemia followed by collapse post-delivery suggests Amniotic Fluid Embolism
 
  • Typically, amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) happens during labor and delivery or in the first few hours following delivery via cesarean section, amniocentesis, placenta removal, or with therapeutic abortion.
 
  • The AFE diagnosis is an exclusionary clinical diagnosis. Based on the clinical presentation, it is made. When the condition first manifests, it frequently manifests as tachycardia with a right ventricular strain pattern and ST-T wave alterations on an ECG, and pulse oximetry may reveal a precipitous decline in oxygen saturation. Following this, there is a collapse of the cardiovascular system and acute respiratory distress along with extreme hypotension.





Reference: Williams Obstretics, 26th edition, Page no 743-745.

questions.text: Which test should be done on a young lady who has a history of recurrent abortions?
questions.solution:
• Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, or APS, is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system produces antibodies that mistakenly attack certain proteins in the body, including proteins found in the blood clotting system.
  • Recurrent abortions is one of the most common manifestations of APS. The most relevant investigation to identify APS is the Dilute Russell Viper Venom Test (DRVVT).
  • This involves measuring the time it takes for blood to clot with the aid of a specific mixture of venom and other factors. Any abnormally prolonged clotting time could indicate the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies, which are indicative of APS.

Laboratory criteria for APS needs presence of any one of the following antibodies: 
  1. β2 glycoprotein-I
  2. Lupus anticoagulant (LAC)
  3. Anticardiolipin antibodies (ACAs)
Lupus anticoagulant (LAC) is a heterogeneous group of antibodies directed against phospholipid-binding proteins. This antibody group induces prolongation in vitro of the prothrombin, partial thromboplastin, and Russell viper venom times. Thus, paradoxically, this so-called anticoagulant is actually powerfully thrombotic in vivo. This is the only APA that has been consistently associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes.
Thus, the DRVVT can be used as a diagnostic tool for APS and the recurrent abortions that may occur as a result.



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1114.

questions.text: A 20-year-old average-weight female complains of oligomenorrhoea along with facial hair. An initial investigation reveals elevated free testosterone levels. On ultrasound, the ovaries were normal. Which of the following could be a likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is the most likely etiology in a 20-year-old average-weight female with complaints of oligomenorrhea (irregular menstrual cycle) and facial hirsutism (excessive facial hair) with raised free testosterone levels (suggesting hyperandrogenism) and normal appearance of ovaries on ultrasound.
She meets two out of the three Rotterdam criteria for PCOS and hence, it's the most likely diagnosis. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3036.
Shaw’s Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314, 315.

questions.text: Which test is used to differentiate maternal and fetal blood cells?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Apt test

The Apt test (also known as alkaline phosphatase test) and the Kleihauer-Betke test (also known as acid phosphatase test) are both laboratory tests used to detect the presence of fetal blood in a sample.
 
  • The Apt test works by measuring the alkaline phosphatase activity in the sample, which is higher in the presence of fetal blood. The Kleihauer-Betke test works by measuring the amount of acid phosphatase present in the sample, which is also higher in the presence of fetal blood. In both cases, if fetal blood is present in the sample, the tests will detect it.
  • However, the Apt test is the preferred test for distinguishing between maternal and fetal blood within the same sample. This is because the activity of alkaline phosphatase is typically much higher in fetal cells than in maternal cells, so the Apt test is more sensitive in detecting fetal cells.
  • The Kleihauer-Betke test, on the other hand, is not as accurate in determining the source of the blood due to the fact that the activity of acid phosphatase is similar in both maternal and fetal cells.




Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition, Page no 301.
Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 358.

II Tumor involves 1 or both ovaries or fallopian tubes with pelvic extension (below pelvic brim) or peritoneal cancer

III Tumor involves 1 or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, or peritoneal cancer, with cytologically or histologically confirmed spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis and/or metastasis to the retroperitoneal lymph nodes

choices.text: Intracavity Brachytherapy followed by External Beam Radiotherapy

questions.text: What is included in the treatment of Ca cervix IIIB?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Intracavity Brachytherapy followed by External Beam Radiotherapy

Stage-Based Management of Localized Cervical Cancer: 
 
Stage Treatment
Early disease Stage IA1 Surgery, total hysterectomy, radical hysterectomy and conization
Stage IA2, IB, or IIA Combined external beam radiation with brachytherapy and radical hysterectomy with bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy for patients with stage IB or IIA disease 

Radical vaginal trachelectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection is appropriate for fertility preservation in women with stage IA2 disease and those with stage IB1 disease whose lesions are \(\leq 2\) cm 

Cisplatin-based chemotherapy with radiation for stage IA-IIA patients who have specific high-risk features (Positive lymph nodes, surgical margins, and/or parametria)
Advanced disease Stage IIB, III, or IVA Cisplatin-based chemotherapy with radiation
Metastatic disease Stage IVB and recurrent cancer Cisplatin on a palliative basis, radiation therapy for control of bleeding and pain, and systemic chemotherapy for disseminated disease including cisplatin, paclitaxel, carboplatin docetaxel, topotecan, and bevacizumab



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 427, 429.

questions.text: When is a woman's heart under the most strain during pregnancy?
questions.solution: The highest volume overload in a parturient due to maximum cardiac output is seen immediately after delivery because the increased uterine contractions during labor cause an increased cardiac output, resulting in a temporary increase in the total blood volume flowing through the circulatory system. This causes an overload on the cardiovascular system and may lead to increased edema, tachycardia, and other symptoms associated with volume overload.

questions.text: Why does a pregnant woman feel lightheaded in the lying, standing for a long time?
questions.solution:
• Supine hypotensive syndrome (also referred to as inferior vena cava compression syndrome) is caused when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava when a pregnant woman is in a supine position, leading to decreased venous return centrally.
  • That's why pregnant women are advised to lie in left lateral position.


Reference-Williams Obstetrics 26th edition Page no 64

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is recommended for a woman who has been diagnosed with carcinoma of the cervix (FIGO STAGING III)?
questions.solution:
• Stage 3 Ca cervix involves spread of cancer to lower 1/3rd of vagina. The mainstay of management of stage 3 is chemoradiation.
  • Surgery is performed up to stage IIa when the size of the tumor is < 4 cm. 
  • Cisplatin or 5-fluorouracil are used as radiosensitizers.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the likelihood that a newborn has RDS?
questions.solution:
• An air bronchogram on the chest X-ray of a newborn is a sign of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS).
  • RDS is a breathing disorder seen in premature newborns that is caused by lack of surfactant, that helps keep the air sacs in the lungs from collapsing.
  • The air bronchogram appears on the X-ray as light-colored streaks of air within the areas of the lungs where there would normally be lungs tissue.
  • Air bronchograms indicate that the affected lung tissue is collapsed and not providing adequate gas exchange for the newborn.
  • Treatment for RDS includes supplemental surfactant, oxygen and other supportive therapies.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page No 165,166

choices.text: IV Antibiotics and Removal of necrosed portion of Intestine

questions.text: What is the treatment for a neonate who has Bell's stage 1 necrotizing disease and is stable?
questions.solution:
Conservative management is done in Bell's stage 1.
