questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a toddler who has a few drops of blood coming out of his rectum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Juvenile Rectal Polyp
 
  • Juvenile rectal polyps are the most common cause of passage of a few drops of blood per rectum in a toddler.
  • They are benign, mushroom-like growths that occur in the lining of the rectum.
  • They typically cause mild rectal bleeding but can also cause discomfort, pain, and bright red blood in the stool or on toilet paper. Other causes of rectal bleeding in toddlers include infections, anal fissures, certain medications, or even foreign bodies in the rectum.
  • This is a bright red, glistening pedunculated sphere (‘cherry tumor’) that is found in infants and children that may persist into adult life.

Reference: Bailey & Love’s SHORT PRACTICE of SURGERY, 28th Edition, Page No 1403.

choices.text: Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizure on going to sleep

questions.text: What is the most typical presentation of JME(Janz syndrome)?
questions.solution:
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) typically begins in childhood or adolescence.
  • The most common clinical presentation of JME is myoclonus (involuntary muscle jerking or twitching), generally most prominent when waking up.
  • When the myoclonus occurs along with other seizure types more frequently and lasts more than a short duration, the diagnosis of JME is more secure.
  • Other seizure types that can occur with JME are tonic-clonic (grand mal), absence (petit mal) and tonic seizures.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3098

questions.text: A child was taken for CECT Chest and Post IV Contrast; the child developed swelling which gradually increased. There is numbness; pain on the passive extension of the fingers.  Pulse was present. Next Step?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Immediate Fasciotomy
 
  • Compartment syndrome is a medical condition caused by excessive pressure within the musculature in a particular area of the body, such as the arm.
  • When contrast medium is injected into an arm, the injection often causes swelling, but if the contrast medium is injected too quickly or in too large of an amount, the excess pressure can lead to compartment syndrome.
  • Symptoms of compartment syndrome can include numbness, pain, and swelling. If not treated quickly, compartment syndrome can lead to permanent nerve or muscle damage.
  • The best treatment for compartment syndrome caused by extravasation of contrast medium is immediate fasciotomy, which is a surgical procedure that relieves the excessive pressure and allows the contrast medium and fluid to be drained.
  • This can offer the patient relief from their symptoms and prevents potentially serious, long-term complications like Volkman's ischemic contracture. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 33.

questions.text: What is the treatment for recurrent URTI in a 5-year-old child with ear problems and mouth breathing?
questions.solution:
Adenoid hypertrophy is caused by enlarged adenoid tissue, which is located in the back of the nose. Recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, nasal obstruction and hearing impairment often accompany adenoid hypertrophy. People with high arched palates are more likely to suffer from adenoid hypertrophy than those with normal palates. The most common management for adenoid hypertrophy is adenoidectomy, which is a surgical procedure to remove the excess adenoid tissue. Grommet insertion may also be used to further improve the symptoms associated with adenoid hypertrophy, such as hearing impairment, by helping to drain the ear wax and other secretions from middle ear.

Reference : P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and Neck surgery , 7th Edition- page 276

questions.text: A child with recurrent seizures, glaucoma, and palpable plaques in the Ophthalmic and Maxillary distribution. Mother complained, it is present since birth and has not changed since then. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Sturge-Weber syndrome, or encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a phakomatosis characterized by facial port wine stains and pial angiomas. 

  • The most common clinical manifestation is with childhood seizures, present in 71-89% of cases.
  • These usually begin in the first few years of life and are often associated with developmental delay and hemispheric symptoms including hemiplegia/hemiparesis and hemianopsia.
  • Approximately a third of patients have choroidal or scleral angiomatous involvement, which may be complicated by retinal detachment, buphthalmos or glaucoma.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3146-3148

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic of basal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution: Nuclear palisading is a characteristic feature of basal cell carcinoma, which is the most common type of skin cancer. This feature is characterized by a distinctive arrangement of nuclei in an orderly row at the periphery of the tumor cell clusters. The orderly arrangement of the nuclei around the clusters of tumor cells is referred to as "palisading" and can be viewed under a microscope. This is one of the primary ways that a pathology lab can make a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man had multiple small hypopigmented patches around his hair follicles on his upper chest and back. Macules had fine scaling that coalesced later.
Before one year, the patient received treatment, and it was successful. Which of the following tests would be most useful??
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis versicolor is a common fungal infection caused by the yeast species Malassezia furfur.
  • It presents as multiple, small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back which are circular, arranged around follicles and can coalesce to form large sheets with fine scaling.
  • The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation.
  • A KOH preparation can be done with a scraping of the affected area, which will show the characteristic short branching adapted yeasts.
  • The fungus can also be seen under the microscope with other staining techniques such as periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) and Giemsa.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.11, 32.12

questions.text: What is the possible diagnosis of a a 13 year old boy with an itchy, erythematous lesion on the face and palms and soles?
questions.solution:
Scabies is an itchy skin condition caused by a tiny mite called Sarcoptes scabiei. Infants with papulovesicular lesions on the palms, soles, face, and trunk may be suffering from scabies. These lesions are small, red bumps filled with fluid or pus that may become crusted over or become open sores.

Other symptoms of scabies include intense itching, especially at night, and itching of the hands, feet, or other areas of the body. Diagnosis of scabies can be made by a dermatologist based on a physical examination of the lesions and a review of the patient's medical history. 

Drug of choice for scabies is 5% permethrin cream applied all over the body except face.

questions.text: A patient has multiple hyperesthetic and hypopigmented patches on the lateral aspect of the forearm with abundant acid-fast bacteria and granulomatous inflammation is seen. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Borderline lepromatous leprosy is a form of leprosy which is characterized by multiple hypoaesthetic and hypopigmented macules on the skin. 


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.8

questions.text: Mid borderline leprosy is characterised by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Borderline(BB) leprosy is characterized by hypopigmented macules or plaques with Annular Swiss cheese/inverted saucer appearance.
  • The lesions are usually variable in number ~ 10-30. 


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10

questions.text: How can you perform a rapid diagnosis on a patient who has had tunneling of two fingernails and one toenail for one year?
questions.solution: Onychomycosis, or Tinea unguum, is a fungal infection that affects the nails, causing discoloration, thickening, and tunneling of the nails. Nail scraping for KOH (potassium hydroxide) is the most important test to diagnose this condition. During a nail scraping test, a sample of the affected nail is scraped off and then examined under a microscope to look for fungal elements. KOH is then applied to the scrapings to observe any changes in the sample that can help to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A boy had itchy, excoriated papules on the forehead and the exposed parts of the arms and legs for 3 years.
The disease was at its worst during the rainy season and completely disappeared during the winter. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Insect bite hypersensitivity (Paederus dermatitis) causes an itchy, excoriated (scratchy) rash on the body when the affected person is bitten by certain insects. In this case, the young boy had itchy, scratchy papules (raised bumps) on his forehead, arms, and legs for three years, with the worst symptoms in the rainy season and complete remission (temporary improvement) in the winter season. This suggests that the boy's skin reactivity to certain insect bites, predominantly in the rainy season, is causing his symptoms. Treatment for insect bite hypersensitivity usually involves antihistamines, topical steroids, and avoiding future insect bites.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 117.11

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with sun exposure?
questions.solution: Actinic keratosis (AK) or solar keratosis is a common condition caused by too much exposure to ultraviolet radiation, often from the sun. It is the result of abnormal skin cell development, with the cells becoming thicker, flatter and more scale-like. This overgrowth can cause rough and red patches to form on the skin. In some cases, AK can develop into a skin cancer. To prevent AK from forming, it’s important to protect your skin from the sun’s ultraviolet rays.

questions.text: When exposed to sunlight, a 23-year-old woman develops brownish pigmentation on her cheeks and bridge of the nose. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution: Chloasma is a skin condition characterised by discoloration of the skin on the bridge of the nose and cheeks, usually triggered by sun exposure. It is more common among pregnant women, but can also be seen in women who are taking certain hormonal medications. It may also be referred to as “pregnancy mask” or “melasma”. The discoloration is not very noticeable in most cases, but can range from mild to severe. Treatment can involve using sunscreen, using medicated creams, and laser or chemical treatments to lighten the affected areas.

questions.text: What is the maximum dose of lidocaine given with adrenaline for ocular surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) 7 mg/kg 
 
  • The maximum safe dose of lignocaine with adrenaline for local blocks in ophthalmic surgeries is 7mg/kg.
  • This means that the total amount of lignocaine with adrenaline prescribed for the local block should not exceed 7mg/kg of the patient’s weight.
  • This has been determined by clinical studies and should not be exceeded without a doctor's approval. A lower dose might be necessary for certain individuals if they have underlying medical conditions.
Formulation Maximum Dose Absolute Maximum
Without Adrenaline 3 mg/kg 200 mg
With Adrenaline 7 mg/kg 500 mg

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 392.

questions.text: Despite being under spinal anaesthesia, a woman who had previously undergone a C-section informed the anesthesiologist that she was aware of the surgery. How should the level of anaesthesia be monitored?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Bispectral Index
 
  • The Bispectral index (BIS) monitor collects raw EEG data through its sensors and uses an algorithm to analyze and interpret the data.
  • The data displays as a number on the BIS view monitor. BIS values range from 0 to 100.
  • A value of 0 represents the absence of brain activity, and 100 represents the awake state.
  • The value at the time of surgery should be between 40-60. 
  • Train of Four (TOF) monitoring is used to assess the level of neuromuscular blockade during anesthesia but is not a direct measure of the depth of anesthesia





Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1282.

questions.text: Which hand would a right-handed individual use to handle the laryngoscope while inserting an ET tube?
questions.solution: A laryngoscope should be held in the left hand by a right-handed person in order to get the best possible view of the larynx when visualizing it for intubation. The left hand is generally better suited for this purpose because it is less clumsy in tight spaces. Additionally, with the left hand on the laryngoscope and the right hand free for other instrumentation and manipulation, the task of intubation can be done more efficiently.

questions.text: A laparotomy is performed on a patient who has a ruptured spleen. 125 beats per minute are being produced by the heart, and the blood pressure is 80/50. What is the preferred induction agent?
questions.solution:
.Correct option: 3. Ketamine
  • Ketamine is an anesthetic agent that is particularly useful in treating hypovolemic shock because of its unique properties which enables it to rapidly increase blood volume, reduce anxiety and restore perfusion of vital organs.
  • Ketamine increases arterial blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output in a biphasic manner. Ketamine causes the systemic release of catecholamines, inhibition of the vagal nerve, inhibition of norepinephrine reuptake at peripheral nerves and non-neuronal tissues such as the myocardium, and norepinephrine release from sympathetic ganglia.
  • It also has fewer side effects compared to other anesthetic agents and can be administered in a safe and effective manner in the setting of hypovolemic shock.
  • In addition, ketamine increases both systolic and diastolic blood pressure while providing effective analgesia.
  • Trauma patients with extensive blood loss (shock) are typical candidates for rapid-sequence anesthesia induction with ketamine.
Thus, Ketamine is the agent of choice in this case.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 664, 665.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida has mitral stenosis and regurgitation and is in labor. She says she wants a natural delivery. Which would be the best way to provide analgesia to the woman?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Epidural Anesthesia
 
  • Epidural anesthesia will result in less hemo-dynamic alteration and therefore, is preferred in patients with heart disease.
  • Neuraxial analgesia is the ideal intervention for labour analgesia in a 26-year old primigravida with severe rheumatic disease (mitral stenosis with mitral regurgitation) who is in early labour and the obstetrician wants to try a normal labour.
  • Epidural (neuraxial) analgesia is the most effective and least depressant method of intrapartum pain relief and is often viewed as technique choice for relief of labor pain. It blunts the hemodynamic effects of contractions and associated pain response, which is desirable for patients with hypertensive disorders, asthma, diabetes, and cardiac and  neurovascular disorders.
  • Epidural labor analgesia is recommended for women with heart disease to decrease catecholamine release and eliminate the increased cardiac output and tachycardia attributable to labor pain. The afterload reduction that occurs with epidural analgesia should be followed closely and may need to be countered with a carefully titrated α-adrenergic agonist to prevent tachycardia and ischemia.
  • Spinal anesthesia, on the other hand, is injected directly into the cerebrospinal fluid and can cause a sudden decrease in blood pressure.
  • This can be dangerous for women with heart disease, especially those with mitral stenosis and regurgitation, as it can worsen their condition and lead to complications.
  • Inhalational analgesia and intravenous opioids are also not recommended for women with heart disease, as they can have adverse effects on the cardiovascular system.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2020, 2030.

questions.text: A patient having severe mitral stenosis undergoes surgery. What is the preferred anesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Etomidate
 
  • Etomidate is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent that is preferred for patients with mitral stenosis because it has minimal effects on cardiovascular function and does not cause significant changes in heart rate or blood pressure.
  • The hemodynamic stability seen with etomidate is due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor. The effect of etomidate on the α2-adrenoceptors generates an increase in blood pressure in vivo; this may contribute to the cardiovascular stability after induction of anesthesia. The minimal effect of etomidate on cardiovascular function sets it apart from other rapid-onset anesthetics.
  • Etomidate has proven useful in patients with valvular or ischemic heart disease undergoing noncardiac surgery and in patients with poor cardiac function.
  • It also has a rapid onset and short duration of action, making it useful for procedures that require brief anesthesia.
  • Thus, Etomidate is the most cardiostable IV anesthetic agent.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 668.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about "Scoline Asphyxia"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (Option 2) It is due to deficiency of Cholinesterase
 
  • Scoline Asphyxia occurs due to prolonged effect of Sch due to presence of abnormal variant of Pseudocholinesterase.
  • Qualitative analysis of Pseudocholinesterase is done by calculating Dibucaine number. Normal value is 80 : 20.
  • Quantitative analysis is done by measuring Plasmacholinesterase.
  • Management of Scoline Asphyxia – Continue mechanical ventilation and administer FFP.
Online Reference: 
Hager HH, Burns B. Succinylcholine Chloride. [Updated 2023 Feb 20]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499984/

questions.text: What makes soda lime so effective at absorbing CO2 in closed-loop anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
• Calcium hydroxide, also known as slaked lime, is the most important constituent of soda lime in a closed circuit system designed for the reabsorption of carbon dioxide (CO2).
  • This is because calcium hydroxide reacts with the CO2 to form calcium carbonate, which is insoluble and can be removed from the system, thus preventing the accumulation of CO2.
  • Additionally, the calcium hydroxide also helps to raise the pH of the system, ensuring that hydroxide ion concentration remains high, which helps to prevent CO2 from being released.
  • As soda lime is widely used in closed circuit oxygen applications, its proper utilization requires calcium hydroxide as the main component.


Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 608, 609.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the decreased requirement for the anaesthetic agent in pregnant women?
questions.solution: In a pregnant female, the enlarging uterus can cause a decrease in the volume of the subarachnoid space, which is the space where spinal anesthetics are injected for pain relief. Additionally, the increased amount of blood flow can cause engorgement of the epidural veins, making it more difficult for the spinal anesthetic agent to reach the nerve fibers. Lastly, the sensitivity of the nerves to the anesthetic agent can increase due to pregnancy hormones, leading to a decreased requirement of the spinal anesthetic agent. However, this decreased requirement is not due to exaggerated lumbar lordosis, which occurs when the lumbar spine curves excessively.

questions.text: What exactly is amifostine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Radio-protector
 
  • Amifostine is a radioprotectant, which is a compound that protects tissue from the damaging effects of radiation.
  • It works by temporarily binding to radiation and preventing it from entering cells and damaging them.
  • When taken before radiation treatment, Amifostine reduces the chances of radiation-induced damage to healthy cells.
  • It is most commonly used to protect the salivary glands and other areas of the head and neck from radiation exposure during radiation therapy for cancer.
Radio-sensitiser examples- oxygen, 5FU, gemcitabine.
Radio-protector examples- amifostine, vitamin A/C/E.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 936.

questions.text: Bracket calcification on Xray is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Lipoma of Corpus Callosum.
 
  • Bracket sign refers to radiographic appearance seen with tubulonodular variety of pericallosal lipoma. 
  • Indicates calcification at the periphery of the midline lipoma.
  • Best seen on coronal imaging and historically was identified on frontal radiographs

 
  • Bracket calcification on skull X-ray is seen in a condition called Corpus callosum lipoma. Bracket calcification, which typically appears on X-rays as a semi-triangular mineralized structure, is believed to be the result of microcalcifications that occur secondary to the lipoma.
  • As the lipomas grow, the pressure has been shown to cause tiny calcium deposits to build up in the affected area, resulting in the bracket calcification seen on the X-ray.


Reference: Gaillard F, Elfeky M, Fortin F, et al. Bracket sign (pericallosal lipoma). Reference article, Radiopaedia.org (Accessed on 18 Sep 2024) https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-9475

questions.text: Where does the maximum radiation exposure occur?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: CT Abdomen 

Radiation exposure of various imaging modalities are listed below: 



 
  • CT scan, or computed tomography scan, is a type of medical imaging that uses x-ray radiations to create detailed, three-dimensional images of internal organs and structures.
  • Compared to other imaging tests, CT scans involve a greater exposure to radiation, and so have the potential to cause more damage to your body’s cells.
  • The maximum radiation exposure occurs during a CT scan due to the combined exposure from multiple x-ray images being taken.


Reference: Smith-Bindman, Rebecca et al. “Radiation dose associated with common computed tomography examinations and the associated lifetime attributable risk of cancer.” Archives of internal medicine vol. 169,22 (2009): 2078-86. doi:10.1001/archinternmed.2009.427

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-iodine contrast?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Gadolinium



Gadolinium is a rare earth element used in medicine as a contrast agent for detecting diseases or abnormalities. It is a non-iodine containing contrast and is classified as an acyclic, ionic gadolinium contrast medium. Gadolinium atoms are paramagnetic and are able to shorten the TI (Tissue-to-background) relaxation time. This property allows medical imaging devices to more accurately detect abnormalities in tissues and organs.

However, gadolinium-containing agents can also cause a toxic reaction known as nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF). NSF has been found to be more common in cases of severe kidney problems and can increase the risk of serious complications. People with compromised kidney function should only receive gadolinium-based agents with extreme caution.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 13.

choices.text: Tumor at the base of tongue with Lymph Node enlargement

questions.text: Where is stereotactic radiotherapy used?
questions.solution:
Stereotactic radiotherapy (SRT) is used in stage 1 lung carcinoma due to its ability to deliver high doses of radiation to a small, well-defined area with great precision. This treatment is especially helpful for cancer located near sensitive organs, such as the heart, lungs, or spinal cord. By focusing on smaller areas, SRT limits radiation exposure to normal, healthy tissue, reducing potential side effects from radiation therapy. Additionally, stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) is a form of SRT which can be used to treat tumors that are too hard to reach with traditional radiation therapy. Stage 1 inoperable lung tumor is a localized lesion whereas rest of the give options involves tumors with extensive spread. Stereotactic means accurate localization. Stereotactic radiotherapy is used to delivery radiation to localized tumors.



Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1738.
Murray and Nadel's Textbook of Respiratory Medicine, 6th edition, Page no 953.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is available in depot form?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Fluphenazine
 
  • Fluphenazine decanoate is an antipsychotic medication that is injected into the muscle (i.m.) for long-term treatment of schizophrenia.
  • The injection can be given as a depot injection, which means that the medication is released slowly over time.
  • This type of injection typically needs to be repeated every 2-4 weeks in order to maintain an effective level of the medication in the body over time. The injection should be done by a healthcare professional, such as a doctor or nurse.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 467.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a disorder of "form of thought"?
questions.solution:
• Amongst the given options, the Thought block (option 3) is the most appropriate answer.
  • Thought blocking occurs when there is a sudden arrest of the train of thought, leaving a ‘blank’. An entirely new thought may then begin.
  • Thought block is a disorder of continuity of thinking (stream of thought), not a disorder of form, which means that thought block is not due to an inability to come up with ideas (form) but instead is due to an inability to maintain a train of thought (stream). People with this disorder may have difficulty organizing or connecting their ideas and concepts together in a coherent way. 
Note: Certain textbooks consider thought block as a disorder of the form of thought. However, Fish's Clinical Psychopathology (followed at AIIMS) clearly mentions Thought block as a disorder of continuity of thinking (stream of thought).
Hence, in INICET, option (3) should be marked [Controversial question]



Reference: Fish's Clinical Psychopathology, 3rd edition, Page no 36.

choices.text: Recall of events and avoidance of trauma

questions.text: What distinguishes PTSD from all other disorders?
questions.solution:
The distinguishing feature of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) from other disorders is:

1. Recall of events and avoidance of trauma.

This is because re-experiencing the traumatic event (through intrusive memories, flashbacks, or nightmares) and avoidance (avoiding reminders of the trauma, such as places, people, or activities that may trigger memories of the event) are hallmark symptoms of PTSD. These symptoms are unique to PTSD and distinguish it from other mental health disorders.

Here’s why the other options aren’t as distinguishing:

  • Option 2 (Nightmares about events): While nightmares are a common symptom of PTSD, they are not exclusive to this disorder. Other anxiety or trauma-related disorders can also involve nightmares.
  • Option 3 (Autonomic arousal and anxiety): Increased arousal and anxiety can occur in several disorders, including generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder, and others.
  • Option 4 (Depression): Depression is a symptom that can be present in various disorders, not just PTSD.

The re-experiencing and avoidance elements are what most clearly define PTSD as a unique disorder.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 440-442.

choices.text: It has control centers for all motor actions and sensory inputs
Its functions can be profoundly affected by the external environment
Every cell of the brain has a specific function
It acts as a closed system, responding to internal stimuli but not the external stimuli

questions.text: Why is it believed that the brain is responsive?
questions.solution:
In humans, the brain is considered to be "responsive" because its functions are affected by changes in the external environment.

For example, changes in the environment (such as a loud noise) can cause the brain to activate certain areas in an attempt to process the change.

The brain is also affected by changes in emotional arousal, where different areas of the brain become more active depending on the emotional context.

Additionally, changes in learning patterns can also cause the brain to rewire itself as new connections are formed and strengthened through repetition.

Finally, when exposed to certain types of drugs or hormones, the brain can make adjustments to its chemistry in order to cope with the changes in the external environment.

Ultimately, the brain is widely seen as being highly responsive to many types of changes in the environment, both physical and emotional.

 

Reference- Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology Edition 26 th Page no 151

questions.text: What is the purpose of Gallows traction?
questions.solution:
• Gallow’s traction is an orthopaedic traction used in infants and children less than 2 years of age for treatment of a fracture shaft of the femur. This traction is used to keep the leg straight, to maintain alignment of the leg bones, and to reduce muscle spasms.
  • Russet's traction or Thomas splint is an orthopaedic traction that is used to treat a fracture shaft of the femur in older children. It is similar to Gallow’s traction, but instead of the leg being suspended in a traction splint, it is secured by a heavy plaster cast. This cast also serves to provide additional support and maintain alignment. This traction also helps to reduce muscle spasms, making the leg more comfortable and easier to manage.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 27

questions.text: A patient was injured in a car accident and sustained a left knee injury. The dial test resulted in a positive result. What could be the source of the problem?
questions.solution:
•  
  • Dial test is used for checking posterolateral instability of the knee joint.
  • The posterolateral corner is a complex that includes that includes the lateral collateral ligament, popliteus tendon,  arcuate ligament, popliteofibular ligament, and the short lateral ligament
  • Tests for posterolateral instability include dial external (lateral) rotation (of tibia) test, external rotation recurvatum test, reverse pivot shift test of Jakob, Hassler and Staubli and posterolateral drawer test.
  • Dial Test / Tibial External (Lateral) Rotation Test With patient in supine or prone position, external rotation of tibia on the femur is measured at both 30° and 90° of knee flexion and compared with the opposite leg.

Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 154

questions.text: A patient complains of back pain that radiates to posterolateral leg, loss of medial hamstring reflex and decreased sensation along anterolateral leg, large toe web and dorsum of foot. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• .The above clinical features are seen due to involvement of L5 nerve root which will be seen in L4-L5 disc prolapse.
  • Option A- L5-S1 disc prolapse will result in compression of S1 nerve root causing loss of ankle jerk and decreased sensation along lateral malleolus, lateral foot, heel and web of fourth and fifth toes.
  • Option C- L3-L4 disc prolapse will result in compression of L4 nerve root causing weakness of quadriceps muscle and decreased sensation along posterolateral leg, anterior knee, medial malleolus and medial foot.


Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 255

questions.text: A person can abduct his arm, rotate it internally, and lay the back of his hand on the lumbosacral joint, but he cannot lift it from behind. What exactly is aetiology?
questions.solution:
• Subscapularis tendon tear occurs when there is  sudden or awkward movement of the arm.
  • Due to the tear, the person is able to abduct the arm and move it away from the body and internally rotate it, due to the downward pull of gravity. However, they are not able to lift it up from the back, Lift off Test.
  • This is because the subscapularis muscle aids in the lifting and adduction of the arm, and its damaged tendon can no longer provide that function.

Lift off test 
 

Reference-:Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma 10th Edition Page no 360

questions.text: The dorsum of a newborn baby's foot cannot touch the anterior tibia because the foot is inverted after birth. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• CTEV stands for Congenital Talipes Equinovarus, which is a birth defect that causes the foot to be inverted (or turned inward) and unable to touch the anterior tibia. 
  • The condition is caused by a number of factors such as genetics, poor nutrition during pregnancy, and certain types of infections.
  • Treatment of CTEV typically involves serial casting, splinting, or surgery to correct the deformity.



Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 212,213

questions.text:
A fever, mid-thigh soreness, and edema are all present in an eight-year-old youngster. On X-ray, Codman's triangle can be seen. Histopathology reveals MIC-2-positive, tiny round cells.
What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Ewing's sarcoma is a rare type of cancer that often affects the long bones of the body, particularly in children and young adults. It typically affects the mid-thigh region in an 8-year old boy, where a swelling with femoral thickening is present. Aspirating the swelling will show greyish white liquid containing atypical round cells that are positive for MIC-2, an important marker for diagnosing Ewing's sarcoma. This confirms the most likely diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma.
Sunray appearance and Codman triangles are usually associated with osteosarcoma, but they are just as common in Ewing's sarcoma. For the diagnosis of osteosarcoma, histopathology must show the presence of immature new bone cells, i.e. osteoid.

questions.text: A patient who overindulged in alcohol the previous evening and dozed off on an armchair arrives at the emergency room. His hand is immobile in the morning, and radial nerve palsy is identified as the cause. What should be the management ?
questions.solution:
This patient has Saturday Night Palsy, a type of radial nerve palsy caused by prolonged compression of the radial nerve in the spiral groove. It occurs when a person falls asleep with their arm hanging over a hard surface (like an armchair) after excessive alcohol consumption.

This condition usually results in neurapraxia (temporary nerve conduction block) rather than permanent nerve damage.  Initial approach is Conservative (Wait & Watch) since most cases resolve spontaneously within 2-4 weeks.

Other options

Option 2 - Knuckle bender splint - Used for ulnar nerve palsy/Ulnar claw hand. 


 

Options 3 - Surgery is only considered if there is no improvement after 3–6 months or if there is severe nerve damage on EMG/NCS.

Option 4 -  Do EMG study after 2 days - Too early EMG/NCS should be done after 3–4 weeks, as early studies may not show nerve conduction abnormalities in neurapraxia.

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 71,64

questions.text:
A senior citizen who had earlier fallen in the bathroom was immobile. Later, she had legs that were rotated externally. Scarpa's triangle and limb were both sensitive.
Pain prevented him from moving around. No hip fracture could be revealed on the X-ray. What comes after this in the procedure?
questions.solution:
• Scarpa's triangle is an anatomical region located around the hip joint, which is vulnerable to fractures due to its delicate bone and tissue structure.
  • An externally rotated leg in this area is indicative of a fracture of the neck of the femur.
  • It is usually caused by a direct impact to the hip and can be accompanied by severe tenderness when touched. Due to the complexity of the hip joint, a fracture of the neck of the femur is often difficult to detect on a standard X-ray. Therefore, an MRI or a bone scan may be needed to confirm the presence of the fracture.

 Reference-: Essential Orthopaedics by Maheshwari Edition 7th Page no 140
